family_friendly.description: Important to know for Laugh Track City or Family Friendly Matinee

categories.name: Opening Games
categories.description: Warm-up and opening games to start a show

games.name: Categories

setup.description: Players stand in a line. Host gets a topic from the audience.

rules: Host points to each player who must name something in the category
Eliminations occur on hesitation, incorrect answers, or host decision
Host may give endowments instead of eliminating (accents, impressions, dance moves)
tips: Practice heightening - start obvious, get more obscure
Listen to fellow players for patterns
Embrace failure - fail big!
Commit to any endowments given

games.name: Home Shopping Network

setup.description: One or two people designated as guessers leave the room. Host collects five items with unique traits (e.g., "microwave POWERED BY tofu"). Clue givers write down items and decide who gives what clue.

rules: One side goes 1‚Üí2‚Üí3, other side goes 5‚Üí4‚Üí3
Guessers race to claim the middle item
Clue givers may ONLY use pantomime, no gibberish
If one guesser, go 1‚Üí5

tips: Be a character - you're a QVC host!
Keep upbeat attitude and energy
Tell a narrative, don't just list guesses
Eyes on clue givers at all times
Cheat out towards audience while ensuring guesser can see
Show the NEED for the product first
Definitively indicate when product is guessed (clap and point)
For non-electric power, pantomime unplugging from outlet

games.name: Mash Up

setup.description: Host creates whiteboard with 4 quadrants, each with a theme (characters, occupation, genre, obsession, location, etc.). Gather 16 total suggestions (4 per quadrant).

rules: Players stand in backline
One player steps up and mashes up two suggestions from different quadrants
Host asks to see the scene
Players do short scene of the mash up
Host walks in front and audience says "MASH UP!" to end scene
Continue until all suggestions are used

games.name: My Movie

setup.description: Players stand in a line with host in front. Get suggestion of a letter or film genre.

rules: Host conducts players to say "My Movie, My Movie, My Movie"
Host points at player who names a made-up movie title using suggestion
When audience/host likes a title (indicated by "oooo"), player gives tagline
If host likes it, they say "let's see it!" and players do short scene
Host calls scene by walking back to middle
Get new suggestion or continue with same

games.name: Playground Insults

setup.description: Host sends one player from each side out as guessers. Get suggestion of insult in form: Adjective ‚Üí Verb-ing ‚Üí Noun (each word 3+ syllables).

rules: Guessers take on personas of kids arguing and insulting each other
Kids face each other with backs to their team's clue givers
Teammates break down syllables and pantomime them
Guessers work guesses into their insults
Host switches between teams every 10-20 seconds
First guesser to call the full insult wins

tips: Character is typically a child on playground
Repeat what other guesser said when clue givers are running on stage
Break down syllables with team beforehand
Have backup pantomimes ready
Syllables don't have to be perfect pronunciations

examples: Air (breathing in air) | Row (rowing a boat) | mat (doormat) | Tic (tic on a dog)
Arrow (Shooting a bow and arrow)
The syllables do not have to be perfect pronunciations

games.name: Scattergories

setup.description: Similar to Categories. Players stand in a line, host gets topic from audience.

rules: Host points to each player who must name something in category
After any response, host can say "Which is also‚Ä¶"
Player must name new topic their response could belong to
Topic changes to this new topic
Eliminations on hesitation, incorrect answers, or host decision
tips: Practice heightening - start obvious, get more obscure
Listen to fellow players for patterns
Embrace failure - fail big!
examples: P1: Shark
P2: Beta Fish
P3: Gold Fish
Host: Which is also a‚Ä¶
P3: Type of Snack
P2: Potato Chips
This game is a chance to practice heightening. Start off with the obvious choices, but challenge yourself to pick more obscure choices each time you are pointed to.
Listen to your fellow players. They might start a game based on the different answers they are giving for a category. One day, I will naturally do a Lion -> Tigers -> Bears -> Oh My!

Embrace Failure! If you start to feel yourself hesitating, throw out a word with all of the confidence in the world. Fail Big! One of my favorite moments in this game is when a player catches the host completely off guard with an item out of left field.
Embrace any endowment you have been given to the best of your ability, even if you have no idea who someone is. Make up a new voice for them and sell it with confidence!

setup.description: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets the suggestion of a Verb-ing ‚Üí Adjective ‚Üí Noun, each word having three or more syllables. The guessers are called back in and take on the personas of politicians debating the pros and cons of Verb-ing ‚Üí Adjective ‚Üí Noun. The politicians face each other with each having their back to the other team‚Äôs clue givers. The host will determine which team will go first, and their teammates will get across the first word by breaking it down into smaller syllable chunks and getting them across through pantomime. The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is working their guesses into their insults. Every ten to twenty seconds, the host will switch between the teams guessing. Once all of the syllables have been given, the guesser will put them together to find the whole word. When the Verb-ing word is guessed, the teams will move on to the Adjective, and then the Noun. The first guesser to call their opponent the Verb-ing, Adjective, that is into Noun wins it for their team.

games.name: Sideline Karaoke

setup.description: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets five multi word songs titles from the audience.

examples: The guessers then run back into the room and each grab a microphone. A pianist or soundbooth will provide a backing track. Similar to Home Shopping Network, each guesser needs to guess two songs and race to get the middle song. Clue givers will be pantomiming entire words to the guessers, which will help the guesser build the whole song title together. The guessers are singing the entire time as they guess the song titles. The first team to guess three songs wins!

games.name: Simon

setup.description: Two players start onstage against each other, similar to What Are You Doing and Top That. The host will then get an activity or location. The first player then does a motion related to the suggestion and names it. The second player then does that first motion, then does a new motion and names it. It then goes back to the first player who does the first motion, then the second, and then a new motion. This goes back and forth until players mess up or the host calls it.

examples: Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball
Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you
Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you ‚Üí I‚Äôm getting a technical by punching you
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you
Host: That‚Äôs wrong!
Top That

Two players start onstage and an activity is suggested from the audience. One player will start by stepping up and doing a quick, repeatable motion, then going back to neutral and saying ‚Äútry that on for size‚Äù or ‚Äútop that.‚Äù The other player will then step up, do the same motion but justify it differently, and then end with ‚Äútry that on for size‚Äù or ‚Äútop that.‚Äù This goes back and forth until an elimination occurs, which comes if a player hesitates, repeats, or the host finds a reason to move the game along.
Player 1: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm playing Basketball‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 2: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm high-fiving a giant‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 1: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm putting things on the top shelf‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 2: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm Mufasa trying to grab Scar‚Äôs paw‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Host: Aww‚Ä¶ too soon, you‚Äôre OUT!
Do a motion that is easily repeatable! If you do something like get on your knees, well you‚Äôre doing it to yourself! If it‚Äôs a motion you can‚Äôt do, do it your own way in safe manner.
For later rounds, avoid doing a motion that was already done. If arms were used up in the air, do something with your legs or use a prop.
The action and first justification should be related to the topic. If it‚Äôs volleyball, it‚Äôs as simple as ‚ÄúI‚Äôm playing volleyball,‚Äù I‚Äôm spiking the ball,‚Äù I‚Äôm setting the ball,‚Äù etc.
The later justifications can be nothing related to volleyball.
Feel free to build a story if it seems possible
‚ÄúI‚Äôm dropping a baby‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm catching that baby‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
Just like What Are You Doing, find ways to throw yourself out if the game goes too long, but make that dive (falling on the grenade) BIG!
Specificity is fun in this game!
Instead of just ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dancing,‚Äù you can say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dancing to Chappell Roan‚Äù
Usually we want to say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶‚Äù at the start of everything, but feel free to switch it up sometimes.
I did a show where the thing was gymnastics and the person threw their arms in the air like a landing pose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing gymnastics‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
My friend said ‚ÄúY‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù (like YMCA by the Village People). Got a major pop!

games.name: Top That (Try That on For Size)

setup.description: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets the suggestion of the types of people the guessers are looking for in the form of Adjective ‚Üí Occupation ‚Üí Hobby, each word having three or more syllables. The guessers are called back in and take on the personas of people looking for love. The guessers face each other with each having their back to the other team‚Äôs clue givers. The host will determine which team will go first, and their teammates will get across the first word by breaking it down into smaller syllable chunks and getting them across through pantomime. The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is while maintaining the character. Every ten to twenty seconds, the host will switch between the teams guessing. Once all of the syllables have been given, the guesser will put them together to find the whole world. When the adjective word is guessed, the teams will move on to the occupation, and then the hobby. The first guesser to say they‚Äôre looking for the Adjective, Occupation, that is into Hobby wins it for their team.

games.name: What You Got

setup.description: A group of 6-8 are onstage in two teams. A suggestion is received from the audience in the form of a broad topic, activity, event, etc. One person from each team is front and center with the other posse members behind that person. To the sound of the beat, the designated leader of Team 1 starts by saying a command and attaching a physical action to it. For example, if the suggestion was ‚ÄúWedding‚Äù, Team 1 Leader may say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm throwing the bouquet.‚Äù with the motion of throwing a bouquet. Once the command is conveyed, the posse members repeat the command and action twice and end with ‚ÄúWhat You Got!‚Äù It then goes immediately to Leader 2 who does a new action.

examples: Leader 1: I‚Äôm Throwing the Bouquet Leader 1 & Posse: Throwing the Bouquet, Throwing the Bouquet, What You Got!
Leader 2: I‚Äôm Giving a Toast Leader 2 & Posse: Giving a Toast, Giving a Toast, What You Got
The teams go back and forth until there‚Äôs hesitation, a fall off the beat, or too much repetition.
This game is all about energy. Be BIG!
Be safe! If you can‚Äôt do the action without hurting yourself, don‚Äôt. However, make up for it with your voice and attitude.
Make sure to attach a specific action to the commands. Even if the command is not action-based, like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm waiting for the bus‚Äù, make it a big action!
If you‚Äôre the leader, be clear and loud. Reach your posse members.
Heighten the commands. Start with typical actions and build up to more absurd or extreme actions.

If you‚Äôre a leader and your opposing leader does a command that elicits a big reaction, feel free to end the round by bowing out of the competition or intentionally losing. It‚Äôs like an edit in a Montage. Let‚Äôs reset with a new round.
Don‚Äôt try to cram big sentences into your actions. Be simple. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm da da da da‚Äù ‚Äîthat‚Äôs it

games.name: What Are You Doing

setup.description: Two players onstage. Suggestions start with actions (sport, chore, hobby), then transition to letters.

rules: One player does random action or dancing
Other player yells "What Are You Doing!"
First player stops, goes to neutral, says something they're NOT doing
Second player does what they were endowed with
Continue until elimination (hesitation, repetition, saying what you're actually doing)
tips: Do big actions and VOCALIZE
Think of these as solo miniature scenes
Avoid narrating/repeating the prompt
Justify absurd actions with big characters
Give and accept the absurd - COMMIT!
Stop action when partner says "What are you doing!" and make eye contact
Try to eliminate "I'm" - use letter sound instead (B-b-b-baking a cake)
"What Are You Doing" is a statement, not a question
Allow partner to finish thought before interrupting
examples: Player 1: Starts Randomly Moving
Player 2: What Are You Doing!
Player 1: Dribbling Basketballs
Player 2: Starts dribbling basketballs
Player 1: What Are You Doing!
Player 2: Shooting Threes
Player 1: Starts Shooting Threes
Have fun with it, you could shoot threes like a basketball game or you could go big game hunting and shoot some threes like they‚Äôre animals
Player 2: What Are You Doing!
Player 1: Traveling
Player 2: 1 airline ticket to Belize, please
Do big actions and VOCALIZE! Make the game equally as fun for a hard-of-hearing audience member and a visually-impaired audience member.
Think of these as solo miniature scenes!

Avoid the trap of narrating your action in a way where it repeats what the prompt was. For example, if someone said ‚ÄúTaking a T-Rex to Dinner.‚Äù Avoid saying things like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm taking this T-Rex to Dinner at Chili‚Äôs.‚Äù It‚Äôs more fun and exciting if you look at them lovingly and say something like ‚ÄúLet me cut up your steak.. I know you can‚Äôt reach them because of your small arms.‚Äù This avoids repeating what the audience already knows about the mini scene.

Justify! When the actions get more and more absurd due to initials, the audience wants to know what this person is thinking, so verbalize that. Use big characters to justify the action. What would a person who is Calming Anxious Lollipop Firefighters (CALF) be thinking/saying? We want to know!
Give and accept the absurd! Sometimes the given statement doesn‚Äôt make sense, choose an action as close to it as possible (doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect) and COMMIT!
Remember to stop your action when your partner says ‚ÄúWhat are you doing!‚Äù and look at them in the eyes to deliver the next action. It shows a transfer of focus.

Try to eliminate ‚ÄúI‚Äôm,‚Äù since it just becomes a delay tactic at that point. Instead, use the sound of the letter to inspire you about an example (eg: B-b-b-baking a cake). The audience thinks that giving us a letter makes the game more difficult, but it is actually a gift we can use to create fun activities.
"What Are You Doing" is a statement (or exclamation) not a question.
Allow your partner to finish their thought before saying "What Are You Doing!" The game should be fast, but thoughts/ideas should be finished.
Don‚Äôt get frustrated; get excited! Short form is designed to make you fail. To be comfortable with failure shows success in short form.

categories.name: Audience Games
categories.description: Games that involve audience members directly

games.name: 4 Square

setup.description: 4 performers in square formation. Front 2 receive suggestion, then rotate.

rules: Front 2 performers receive suggestion
Host shouts "rotate right" and square shifts
New pair front and center receives suggestion
Continue until all 4 pairs have suggestions (you're in 2 pairs)
Front pair jumps into scene when game begins
Host shouts "rotate right (or left)" to end scene and rotate
tips: When you return to scene, time has passed - heighten to new moment
Think cause and effect
Have strong relationship
Listen to host - they may rotate different direction or multiple times

games.name: Audience SFx

setup.description: Audience member given microphone to provide sound effects. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Audience member provides sound effects based on scene actions
Players must justify all sound effects given
tips: Use exposition to help audience member know what you're doing
Verbally announce actions: "Hold on, let me get the axe"
JUSTIFY all sound effects - react appropriately
Allow pauses for sound effects
Play tennis - take turns prompting (50/50)

setup.description: Two teams of 3 (or 4) compete to win the favor of an audience member. Based on a suggestion, the teams try to come up with the best pick up line, but they must speak one word at a time. Teams conclude their pick up line by saying "YEAAAAAHHHHH!" together. The audience member awards a point to one of the teams per round. When you receive the suggestion, freely associate words in your head and see if you can drop them into your team's pick up line. So if the suggestion was rabbit, rather than actually saying the suggestion in the pick up line, try to drop in an association word. "Hey baby, I think you should hop into my heart." "What‚Äôs up doc, you could never bug me." Similar to what you do in the stand-in-the-line pun games like ‚ÄúI Kissed A‚Ä¶‚Äù Since you're speaking one word at a time, the biggest focus is on speaking quickly and coherently. So use proper grammar. Also project and speak clearly. Be confident! Especially with the "YEEAAAAAHHHHH!" If a mistake happens, don't call it out, just finish the line confidently. Your pick up line is awesome, unless you tell the audience it isn't. Vary up your responses. A few types of responses are to try a short pick up line (they can be 2-3 words and that‚Äôs all you need), start with a Question then Answer it, change tone (usually sexy is what we default to, but maybe trying loving or enthusiastic

This game is similar to 4 Square, except the audience volunteer is in every scene and every scene is a three-person scene. 4 Performers are onstage in a square formation with the audience member in the middle. The front 2 performers receive a suggestion. The host shouts rotate right. The square shifts, which means a new pair is front and center. That pair receives a suggestion, and the process continues until all 4 pairs receive a suggestion (so you‚Äôre in two trio scenes for this game). When the game begins, the pair front and center jump into a scene. When the host shouts ‚Äúrotate right (or left)‚Äù the scene ends and the square rotates appropriately.

games.name: Moving Bodies

setup.description: Players cannot move on their own. Audience member moves them like action figures.

rules: Players cannot move themselves
Audience member physically moves players
Players must verbally indicate desired movements
Adjust and justify if audience member moves you unexpectedly
tips: Verbally indicate movements: "I'm walking over there to pick up that basket"
Repeat if volunteer doesn't respond
Justify overzealous movements

setup.description: Peter Pan‚Äôs Shadow (Virtual Reality)

games.name: Slo-Mo Olympics

setup.description: Olympic event of mundane/non-sport activity. Get suggestion.

rules: Athletes warm up at regular speed while being introduced
Starting pistol fires (or commentators start match)
Athletes switch to slow motion
Commentators describe as high-stakes sporting event
Game ends when athlete crosses finish line or vanquishes opponent

tips: Start strong - welcome audience, introduce yourself, event, then athletes
React to what athletes are pantomiming
Play with athletes - instant replays, zoom in
Lead athletes to actions
Don't talk over fellow commentator
Maintain excitement, avoid dead air
Before match, hint at character - good guy (face) or bad guy (heel)
Play with props related to competition
Go slow when match starts, match competitor's speed
Make pantomiming distinct, especially hands
React big with movements and facial expressions
Earnestly do activity first, then sabotage opponent
Use things related to activity when sabotaging
Do 4-5 fighting beats during slo-mo
Generally bad guy should lose

notes: This can be played with an audience member as an athlete. As the fellow athlete, take care of the audience member and let them win.

setup.description: The host first interviews a volunteer about a recent major life or positive decision they made, then ask follow up questions like who they were with when they were making the decision (family, friend, partner, etc.), whom the decision affected, and any other natural questions that come up. The interview should be quick. One player must play the volunteer (either the volunteer chooses or players choose) and the other players will play supporting roles. The scene plays out as if the volunteer had made a different choice, which unravels into them clearly choosing the wrong path. 1st Scene: Establishing the decision and choosing the alternate path 2nd Scene: The initial fallout of the decision showing it was bad 3rd Scene+: Heightening, making things worse (can be multiple scenes) End with asking the volunteer, ‚Äúaren‚Äôt you glad you made that decision?‚Äù

categories.name: Host Interrupt Games
categories.description: Games where the host can interrupt and modify the scene

games.name: 4 Square

setup.description: 4 performers in square formation. Front 2 receive suggestion, then rotate.

rules: Front 2 performers receive suggestion
Host shouts "rotate right" and square shifts
New pair front and center receives suggestion
Continue until all 4 pairs have suggestions (you're in 2 pairs)
Front pair jumps into scene when game begins
Host shouts "rotate right (or left)" to end scene and rotate
tips: When you return to scene, time has passed - heighten to new moment
Think cause and effect
Have strong relationship
Listen to host - they may rotate different direction or multiple times

games.name: Conjunction Junction

setup.description: Players begin neutral scene. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host interrupts and calls out conjunction (and, or, but, because, also, etc.)
Last player who spoke repeats conjunction and expands sentence
Host may call multiple conjunctions in a row

games.name: Forward Reverse

setup.description: Scene game where host can shout 'reverse' to make scene go backwards. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host shouts 'reverse' and scene progresses backwards
Host says 'forward' to resume forward motion
Scene may go in reverse beyond first sentence
tips: Driven by action and characters
Combine dialogue with specific movement/action
Use whole stage, move around
Keep dialogue concise for easier memory
Think in reverse - set up the activity you started with
Don't worry about mistakes, embrace them
Keep momentum going

games.name: Hey Morty

setup.description: Scene game best played dramatically. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Players perform dramatic scene
Host interrupts by calling player's name and repeating a word (usually noun)
Player tells pun based on word in over-the-top manner

Format:
   - Player: "Hey, Morty!"
   - All: "Yeah, Morty?!"
   - Player: "Did you hear the one about X?"
   - All: "No, Morty. We didn't hear the one about X."
   - Player: [Pun]
   - ALL: "HA!" [with jazz hands]
Scene continues as if pun never happened
tips: Pun doesn't have to be good - fun, stupid vibe
Players not in scene can jump on stage for call and response

games.name: New Choice

setup.description: Host can call NEW CHOICE and player must say something different. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host calls NEW CHOICE on player
Player must say something different from what was said
Host may NEW CHOICE actions, reactions, or anything
tips: Keep sentences short with pauses
Make actual change, don't just repeat differently
Change beginning of sentences, not just last word
Think Rule of Threes: Regular > Weird > Crazy Town
Character motivations can remain intact
Prompt host with nice gifts to NEW CHOICE
examples: "Surprise, I got you a new car!" *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a half-eaten Snickers bar.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
"I married your daughter, we cool?"
Keep sentences short with pauses in between lines to allow room for *NEW CHOICE* to be called.
Try to make an actual change and not repeat what you said differently.
Mainly say a new choice; get away from the first choice in some way
A trick to avoid this is by changing up the beginning of your sentences. A trap people often get in is just changing the last word.
AVOID:
‚ÄúYou look beautiful.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look awful.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look suspicious.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look like you could use a shower.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look meh.‚Äù
Think Rule of Three‚Äôs with your new choice: Regular > Weird > Crazy Town
Your character‚Äôs motivations can remain intact, even if the new choices adds twists and turns
Be conscious of ways to prompt the host to *NEW CHOICE*, you want to do things where the host think, ‚Äúthis is a nice gift to *NEW CHOICE*‚Äù
The host is also a player in this game too and it‚Äôs fun when the host is clearly messing with the players on stage.

setup.description: Cast members do a scene and at any point in time, the host can shout "FREEZE". Cast members stand still and the host will prompt each player to make a choice on "What happens next..." Once every player says their thing, the host will have each player repeat it so the audience can vote on which choice they want to see based on their applause. The scene is generally heightened by the amount of players. Sell your choice with your voice and body language Typically Option A (the 1st choice) will be a more logical choice Options B - D can be more extreme and heightened Try to make your choices relevant to the story It‚Äôs okay if they go off the rails because you said the first thing that came to mind, I would rather have you say something than spend time thinking in silence Using ‚ÄúWE‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äù invites everyone be involved in the scene Once the audience has voted for the choice they want to see, immediately start transitioning to that choice and justifying it

The players start out doing a neutral scene based on the suggestion. Whenever the host wishes, they yell out ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù and the players must immediately switch from their normal scene to a Shakespearean inspired play. The host will then yell ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù again and the players will return to the neutral scene. The host may call ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù whenever they like throughout the scene until the game ends. Moments that happened in the scene may carry over throughout the switches, but the fun of it is justifying differently. In the Shakespearean mode, you challenge someone to a duel. Then when you switch to a neutral scene, it‚Äôs now a bar fight. In a neutral scene you take an Uber, but in the Shakespearean lens it is a horse-drawn carriage. Do NOT overuse -TH at the end of every word. It is an old trope that just conveys you don‚Äôt know Shakespeare. Thou is commonly used, so that‚Äôs fine. Shakespearean language can be very ‚Äúflowery‚Äù and passionate. Rather than just saying ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù it‚Äôs more like ‚ÄúMy passion burns for you like the heat bearing down from the sun.‚Äù How to sound Shakespearean: You do NOT have to force a British or Italian accent. Instead, lean into the emotion you‚Äôre conveying with FORCE. Be passionate, be overwhelmed with grief or guilt, etc. Keep in mind themes found in Shakespear plays, just like when you play Genre Replay. Common themes are love, betrayal, death, witches/oracles, etc. Just because Shakespear sounds fancy, keep in mind that he was also a raunchy writer too. Bonus points if you can make your Shakespearean dialogue rhyme!

categories.name: Justification Games
categories.description: Games requiring quick thinking and justification

games.name: 90-Sec Alphabet

setup.description: Scene where each line starts with next letter of alphabet. Get scenario and starting letter.

rules: First word of first sentence begins with given letter
Next line begins with next letter, continuing through alphabet
Goal: get back to starting letter within 90 seconds
tips: Tell beginning, middle, and end within 90 seconds
Start in the middle of action
Use emotions and be a character
Do activities with your lines
You WILL make mistakes - get back on the bike
Don't panic or show WTF expression
Jump out of plane, figure it out on way down
Start with syllable of letter if you blank
examples: Performer A: Frank, looks like we‚Äôre going to have to close down. Nobody wants to eat at Denny‚Äôs anymore.
Performer B: Gosh darn it. What will the 3am boozehounds do without us?
Performer A: I don‚Äôt know (WHOOPS, skipped H)
Performer B: (going with the partner) James! We should fundraise
right now and see if we can make 2k by the end of the day.

Usually, a mistake is temporary. I do this a lot, and a lot of the time, I recognize I messed up and without calling attention to it, I just listen to my partner and go with them. Get back on the bike. I would recommend not backtracking too much, since our goal (through hell or high-water) is to try to get all the way through the alphabet. So, focus and listen, and when a mistake happens, focus and listen stronger to get back on the bike.

A big saying in improv is "Jump out of the plane and figure out what to do on the way down." This rule REALLY applies in this game. Sometimes you get to a letter, and you blank on the "right" word to say. Just say something! Feel free to start with a syllable that begins with that letter and see where it leads. That's the fun of the game, right? The audience is in on this joke that you have these rules to follow.
Performer A: Ulysses, I'm afraid I'm going to have to let you go. Starbucks is making budget cuts.
Performer B: Vooooooocation school! I should have done vocation school! Now I don't have any skills.

setup.description: Ask for a scene suggestion and a letter of the alphabet. The letter becomes the first letter of the first line dialogue. Lines of dialogue alternate between actors, each beginning with the next letter of the alphabet, continuing until the host calls the game.

games.name: Acromania

setup.description: Perform a regular scene based on any suggestion. During the scene, an improviser may throw out an acronym of two or more letters. Another improviser must immediately give the full name the letters represent. GRAMMAR NOTE: No, these aren‚Äôt really acronyms because acronyms are pronounced as words (ex: LASER, SCUBA, FOMO). The abbreviation of a phrase pronounced by saying each letter is called an ‚Äúinitialism.‚Äù I guess it was too obscure to call this game ‚ÄúInitialismania.‚Äù

examples: Person 1: I‚Äôll handle the dinner for tonight. All I need to do is call PTD.
Person 2: Preserve This Dinner? Great idea! They saved many events for me!
Don‚Äôt worry about what the letters could mean, that's up to the other improviser.
Don‚Äôt get caught in a letter rut, like starting or ending with all the same letters.
Get out an acronym earlier in the scene to show how the game works.
Add more letters later in the scene. As a gimmick, end with a long acronym.

Try to make the interpretation of the acronym appropriate in the context of the scene. If it‚Äôs not, however, don‚Äôt worry too difficult. In a case of a weird acronym interpretation, anyone in the scene may help with the justification.
notes: GRAMMAR NOTE: No, these aren't really acronyms because acronyms are pronounced as words (ex: LASER, SCUBA, FOMO). The abbreviation of a phrase pronounced by saying each letter is called an "initialism." I guess it was too obscure to call this game "Initialismania."

setup.description: Two improvisers portray gods who stand on the sides of the stage and at least 2 others are ‚Äúmortals‚Äù performing a scene. Each god‚Äôs powers are influenced by an audience suggestion and the scene gets its own suggestion, something simple like a location. The two mortals begin a scene. At any point, either god may clap to freeze the scene and insert a plague, problem, or solution based on their power. The mortals continue the scene, now influenced by the god‚Äôs interference. It is up to you whether the gods are angry with each other, with the mortals, or with one mortal in particular. The gods may each be trying to plague the other‚Äôs favorite, or they may simply love to interfere. Be clear what kind of gods you wish to use. Suggestions for the gods‚Äô powers may be as simple as asking for a noun, though you do risk having strange, limited powers (‚ÄúGod of Fingernails!‚Äù) Asking instead for the audience to fill in the blank (‚ÄúThis is the god of what?‚Äù) or guiding them to a more sweeping suggestion (‚ÄúGive me a broad category; for example, animals‚Äù) may get you interesting results. If you wish, include a third, benevolent god who can undo any other god‚Äôs meddling.

games.name: Are You Thinking What I‚Äôm Thinking?

setup.description: During a scene, any actor may turn to another and say, ‚ÄúAre you thinking what I‚Äôm thinking?‚Äù The other performer will try to say it along with them, this can be achieved with the initial actor elongating the ‚Äúare.‚Äù They will then try to speak at the same time their answer, then accept that choice. Variation: One actor initiates the ‚ÄúAre you thinking what I‚Äôm thinking?‚Äù The other performer then answers that question and offers a choice or a response. The initial actor accepts that offer immediately. This could be a good exercise for early improvisers working on acceptance.

For four improvisers performing three scenes with three separate suggestions. In the first scene, Actor 1 performs a short scene with Actor 2. In the second scene, Actor 2 performs a scene with Actor 3, but repeats all the lines they had in the scene with Actor 1. Their actions and the way they say the lines may adjust, but the words stay the same. In the last scene, Actor 3 performs a scene with Actor 4, with Actor 3 repeating all their lines from the previous scene. To increase the chances of remembering the dialogue, keep the scenes short and the dialogue distinct. Actors 2 and 3 should avoid overly scene-specific dialogue, like names, that won't carry through as well. The actors who have open dialogue need to pay close attention to the previous scene in order to help the actor who must only repeat their words.

games.name: Hesitation

setup.description: Players gesture to audience to fill in blanks during scene. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Players do scene and gesture to audience for fill-in-the-blank
Player repeats whatever word they hear from audience
Player must justify the word in context

setup.description: Four players start by facing the back wall and covering their ears and humming so they can‚Äôt hear. One at a time, the host will call someone up and ask the audience for their trigger and then response. Example: Whenever B looks into A‚Äôs eyes, A must shimmy and say ‚ÄúI love you!‚Äù The host repeats this until everyone has a trigger and response and it should form a complete cycle. Players will then play the scene normally but work in the triggers and responses, and try their best to justify why they are responding how they are in the scene. The scene needs to start with two people where one person triggers another. You should know who your trigger is before the scene starts Remember that this is still a scene, establish that who, what, why Don‚Äôt try to force the trigger immediately, let it happen naturally at first Let it descend into chaos during the second half of the scene, but make sure to not talk over each other Try justifying the movements and phrases when you make your response

The host assigns each player a word that might come up in a casual conversation, gets a suggestion, and the players begin a neutral scene. Whenever another player in the scene speaks a player‚Äôs word, that player must enter or exit. If the player‚Äôs word is spoken and they are off stage, they must immediately come on stage and justify their entrance. If their word is spoken while on stage, they must immediately exit and justify their exit. Find ways to organically say someone else‚Äôs trigger word so they can enter and leave the stage Someone‚Äôs trigger word could be ‚Äúnight,‚Äù so you can say ‚ÄúI had a good night‚Äôs rest after watching the game.‚Äù Justify why you entered or exited boldly, other players should let you have this moment Never leave an empty stage. If it happens, someone just walk back on. Embrace the silly moments where you accidentally say your own trigger word and need to leave

Players exit the room while the host gets lines of dialogues and actions from the audience that they spread across the stage. There will typically be 4 different prompt types on the slips of paper: Say (Sometimes, the dialogue is just in quotation marks), Do, Enter, Exit. Players will return into the room and do a scene while periodically picking up slips of papers and following the instructions on them. This is a game that is all about justification around what you picked up, and it is almost always easier to justify something after you know what it is rather than before. Don‚Äôt try and set up the line, instead justify it after you picked it up. This is especially important as the slip you picked up may not even be a line at all. Incorporate what your line says into the scene, the fun part of the justification is that your slip of paper is now a part of the reality in your world. Sonia did a great job during the razor scene with Justin where her line told her to play the guitar and that ended up informing her character's wants and desires for the rest of the scene. She also kept that guitar with her throughout the scene as a way to demonstrate the new reality. If there is a slip of paper that is on stage left and next to the wing, then that slip will likely say ‚ÄúEnter‚Äù on it. If you are one of the players who is off to the side then that slip of paper is an invitation for you to pick it up when you want to enter the scene. Try throwing a transition or two into the scene. Especially if you have 3 or 4 players. A transition is a great way to give your fellow players a chance to set up where the scene goes next and helps to keep the game fresh.

Sit, Stand, Kneel, Lie (Sit, Stand, Lie) Can either be played with three or four performers. Each performer must be doing one of the commands during the scene, either sitting, standing, kneeling, or lying down (or just sitting, standing or lying down if there are three performers). If two or more are doing the same command, the audience will let the players know, and the players must quickly adjust. Don't play the game safe. Make bold choices to change your position to cause a change in others. Changes can come naturally (you need to change a tire on the other side of the stage, so you need to stand up to do that), or to mess with your scene partners (you notice someone is sitting, so you choose to sit right next to them, causing them to change) Find new beats in the scene to create new opportunities. If you are doing a scene set around a book club and the scene continues and you're still just talking about books, throw in a choice to change it up. "Hey...maybe this week we watch a movie adaptation of a book..." This creates opportunity to now interact with a TV, maybe change your spot onstage to the couch. Grab some drinks. From this, conflict can also come. "Wait a minute! What the heck are we doing!? This betrays what Book Club is all about." So maybe this person goes to unplug the TV in a bending position. The scene has an easier time progressing and an easier time playing the game if you find new moments through Yes And. The game generally ends quick. The changing of the positions starts at a normal pace (not too slow though, we need to teach the audience the game), but as the game concludes, it'll become more frantic and positions will change way more. Enjoy the chaos and don't lose momentum as you reach the climax. Six Lines (Eight Lines)

games.name: Sit, Stand, Kneel, Lie (Sit, Stand, Lie)

setup.description: 3 Performers. 2 Performers receive 2 sentences each from the host. They are only allowed to use these 2 sentences in the scene. The 3rd performer can say whatever they want in the scene. Two Line Performers Generally, the two lines that are received for the 2 performers are more open-ended. They aren't super specific, which leaves them open for interpretation. Typically, there's one question and one statement. Use that to your advantage. Use object work Explore the environment. Even though you have only two lines, you are still very much helping build the scene. The set-up to the scene might make the Two Line Performers out to be nuisances, but they are integral to the comedy. Use body language, hold and use things in your environment. Your made-up world will give your two lines extra context. Change your tone The line: "How did that get here?" can mean so many different things if you change your tone. Say that line right now with anger. Now with amazement. Now with fear. Now with curiosity. See? It means something different each time. You can also change your volume. A projected whisper in the ear can be much different from a projected shout from across the room. Change who you are addressing You don't have to just address the 3rd performer. There's a tendency to do this, but perhaps address the other Two Line Performer to change the scene dynamics. Colin - The 3rd Performer This person can say and do anything. They have no restrictions. This means they have to make sense of the world and what's happening. Generally, the Colin (I'm calling this person Colin, because Colin almost always plays this role) initiates the scene. Make a strong clear offer and immediately add some emotional stakes. Don't say "Hi, how are you?" Say "We are surrounded. I think we might have to surrender or face certain death." Give specific responses and offers throughout. Help guide the scene to various beats (beginning, middle, end). Even though the challenge of this scene is amongst all 3 performers, if you are Colin, then you have the more obvious challenge to the audience. You are the juggler of the scene and must do your best to keep balance with the scenic restrictions. The comedy is seeing you keep balance onstage. Have fun with this challenge. It's a blast!

Players leave the room, while the host retrieves lines of dialogue from the audience. Players then do a scene and periodically pick up a line, read it, and incorporate it into the scene. Set up a strong initiation to the scene before picking up the first line (know the who, what, where...why is today important, create at least one character who the audience can empathize with). Use the lines in increments of about 15-20 seconds (Duck, duck, goose...the line is the goose). Don't worry about exposition to the lines ("Well my grandfather used to tell me...."You're fired!"). It's easier to just pick up a line and read it and let it impact the relationship you have established. What grandpa said doesn't matter, it's what you're saying right NOW to your scene partner. Justify the lines as well as you can. You might receive some curveballs, but make them work as best as you can. Again, they can be said as expressions/metaphors if they don't make sense. Sometimes, the justification of said line becomes the new reality of the scene. Accept it and proceed! If a fellow player has picked up a line, give focus to them. Read the line clearly, the audience wants to hear them because that‚Äôs the gimmick! Especially if it‚Äôs their suggestion being read out loud.

categories.name: Replay Games
categories.description: Games involving replaying scenes in different styles

setup.description: Countdown (Fairy Tale) The host will get a fairy tale or movie and have the audience member quickly explain it. The performers must perform the entire story within about 90 seconds. (Try to show it in 3-4 scenes). The story must then be redone but in less time (45 seconds, 20 seconds, 10 seconds). Sometimes, the host will not get a fairy tale or story already created and the players will get the opportunity to do a 90-second scene based on any suggestion. Treat it like the base scene for a replay game and aim for strong anchor points and multiple scenes. Honor the audience member‚Äôs summation, especially if they say something odd! Did they just say Cinderella attends the ball in a giant mech suit? It‚Äôs in the scene You can throw in your own knowledge of the story, but try to focus on what the audience member said. Don‚Äôt use too much dialogue, use actions instead as they are easier to remember. Short sentences are your friend. Mark your transitions by leaving the stage and signaling it‚Äôs time for the next scene. ‚ÄúOh the ball will begin any moment, I must leave!‚Äù Use Anchor Points! Anchors are big vocal or physical moments in your scene. If a big physical action happens and it gets a pop from the audience, it must happen every time Don‚Äôt start out frantic during the base scene and first replay (45-second scene). Listen for the time calls as the host yells out how much time is remaining Fun fact: the host isn‚Äôt exactly calling the end of the scene at the exact time. As hosts, we are looking for that button. We fake the time calls all the time.

The players split themselves up into three equal sized groups (A, B, C). The host sends group C out of the room before getting a suggestion for the scene. Group A will then perform a scene based on the suggestion while group B watches. Once the establishing scene is completed the audience will call group C back into the room. Group B will then repeat the first scene while only speaking gibberish. Finally, group C will replay the same scene while re-translating the gibberish back into english. Establishing Scene: Interact with objects in your environment. You want to give the next two groups different motions and items that they will be playing with and using. Create landmark moments for the audience to recognize when the scenes are repeated. Gibberish Scene: Focus on the specific player that you will be reenacting. Make sure that you and your partner are focusing on different players. This is an excellent opportunity for you to practice your gibberish. Vary it up, and use it as you would if you were speaking normally. Bonus points if there is a repeated phrase in the establishing scene and you use a repeated gibberish phrase to copy it. Keep an eye out for big moments that happen throughout the establishing scene. These will be the landmarks that the audience will want to see repeated. Translation Scene: Focus on the specific player that you will be reenacting. Make sure that you and your partner are focusing on different players. If you clearly know what the scene is about just from the gibberish and pantomime, subvert it and make the scene something else.

The initial scene will be about a minute. Try to interject (CUT CUT CUT!) when the scene reaches a solid moment to conclude on. Allow for Person C to get a moment to heighten (usually Person C's contribution creates the most comedy/drama...they are heightening and making the scene bigger). Don't wait too long though. If Person C is taking too long, they had their chance, get out there; keep the show going. Be a character! You don't have to just come in and give the endowment and leave. The character of the director is also a big part of this game. Choose a voice, physicality, way you speak, etc. Banter for a bit (not toooo long!) and then endow! Really pay attention to the scene. You can be inspired by the way they performed to endow. If the scene was action based (or even not action based), you can give them a more physical endowment (do it again as interpretive dancers! do it again as laughing hyenas! do it again as Californian bodybuilders!). If the scene was emotional or not emotional, you can give them an emotional endowment (do it as a soap opera! do it as a war movie! do it as robots!) You can heighten an idea or even change it completely with the endowment. You can also be more random but try to find a link to the previous scene, so that there's a connection! I would recommend starting with not a super crazy endowment to start (you're teaching the game with the first endowment). With the second one, sure, you can go a bit more off-the-wall, but again, try to have a connection! You're essentially a character-based host in this game. So, get out there and call the scene when you feel it's right!
Perform a short G-rated scene. Replay the same scene, but now with a PG-13 rating. Replay once more with an R-rating.

A standard set-up scene is done, and then 2 or 3 tv or movie genres are received from the audience. Sometimes, the host gets emotions and the players will decide which emotions they will embody. The performers must replay the scene 2 (or 3) times using those genres. Make the set-up scene strong with good relationships, actions and aim for at least one scene transition. The host or the players will choose which order to go in. Players choose: Choose the genres you‚Äôre confident in first and third, with the weakest sandwiched in the middle Anchors in your set-up scene are great gifts during the replay scenes The genre can morph characters, environment, situations, etc. Have fun with the genre! Even if you don‚Äôt know a whole lot about a genre, see if you can pull one or a few things and just commit to that choice. One of my favorite sayings in improv is having your pop culture knowledge ‚ÄúA few feet deep, but 1000 feet wide.‚Äù I have not seen a lot of classic movies, but I know the main story beats and references to movies like Titanic, Scarface, etc. If I ever get those suggestions for a scene, I can pull a few things from my limited knowledge and commit 100% to those choices. This knowledge can easily apply to genres! Think of the common tropes that appear in tv and movie genres

The players will first do a base scene for about 90 seconds. Then the host will call all players in a line and ask the audience to vote, with their cheers and applause, for who they would like ‚Äúdead‚Äù when they replay the scene. Once that player is ‚Äúdead,‚Äù the player will then be puppetted around by the other players in the scene like a ‚Äúdead‚Äù body, inspired by the movie Weekend at Bernie‚Äôs. This will be replayed again until there is only one surviving player doing a scene by themselves with the rest being ‚Äúdead.‚Äù Make the set-up scene strong with good relationships, actions and aim for at least one scene transition. Give yourself ‚Äúgifts,‚Äù but make sure you do it safely! If you‚Äôre going to go through a window because you know the audience will love to see that happen, make sure you are safe The audience typically votes for the following player to stay alive at the end: The person who did the least The person who is ‚Äústruggling‚Äù the most in the game The person who is the smallest Try your best to pay attention during the base scene because you may have to fill in the blanks in the replay scenes. You don‚Äôt have to say everything verbatim, as long as you get the gist of what was said. Feel free to trim the fat. As a dead body, do not deadweight. Don‚Äôt be a jerk, it‚Äôs selfishly funny for you and can hurt people who are lifting you. As a dead body, you ultimately have control of your body. The people puppetting you around are only suggesting you to move, but dead bodies should maintain ultimate control. As a puppeteer, feel free to play up the ‚Äústruggle‚Äù of moving these ‚Äúdead‚Äù bodies around. When I‚Äôm out of sight line, I like getting up and moving to make it easier for my puppeteers. I like staying dead during the voting phase if I was already dead, just for fun.

categories.name: Scene Games
categories.description: Traditional improv scenes with various constraints

setup.description: Similar to the game Freeze, except all players will stand on the back wall facing away from the audience so they cannot see the scenes, only hear. At any point and time during the scene someone can say FREEZE and should raise their hand. The person who called freeze must run up, tap out a player, take their EXACT position, and start a new scene based on the position of the players. Do not stay in the same position for more than 2 freezes. Move around, create more opportunities for physically fun freezes. Let scenes develop for a bit. Don‚Äôt call freeze after 2 seconds because you have an idea. Listen to the audience to call freezes. If there‚Äôs a pop, call freeze even if you don‚Äôt have an idea. Just get up there and figure it out! Be specific! If you start a scene lifting something, name what it is you're lifting. You only have 10-15 seconds to give this idea context. Since you only have a few moments, just get straight into the scene. Make bold choices and have big reactions! Scenes shouldn‚Äôt last too long though. Don‚Äôt let scenes die! Sometimes, a scene is just one joke that kills (called ‚Äúblackout scenes‚Äù). Listen to that pop! Since you cannot see, it is even more important to listen to those pops and the energy dying from a scene. Get up quick! When you call freeze, don‚Äôt walk up, run up and take the spot immediately! A third person or more can enter a scene. Usually this person would heighten. If a freeze is called, the person entering can tap out two people and take on one of their positions, or tap out one person and continue doing a 3 person scene (this is just a little bit tricky to justify, so I recommend returning to a 2 person scene eventually). This is a great game to do callbacks to previous fun moments throughout the show or even the game (give it a couple of scenes if you want to callback a previous scene from the game).

The classic game where players start a scene based on a suggestion and at any point and time during the scene someone can say FREEZE! The person who called freeze must run up, tap out a player, take their EXACT position, and start a new scene based on the position of the players. Do not stay in the same position for more than 2 freezes. Move around, create more opportunities for physically fun freezes. Let scenes develop for a bit. Don‚Äôt call freeze after 2 seconds because you have an idea. Listen to the audience to call freezes. If there‚Äôs a pop, call freeze even if you don‚Äôt have an idea. Just get up there and figure it out! Be specific! If you start a scene lifting something, name what it is you're lifting. You only have 10-15 seconds to give this idea context. Since you only have a few moments, just get straight into the scene. Make bold choices and have big reactions! Scenes shouldn‚Äôt last too long though. Don‚Äôt let scenes die! Sometimes, a scene is just one joke that kills (called ‚Äúblackout scenes‚Äù). Listen to that pop! Get up quick! When you call freeze, don‚Äôt walk up, run up and take the spot immediately! A third person or more can enter a scene. Usually this person would heighten. If a freeze is called, the person entering can tap out two people and take on one of their positions, or tap out one person and continue doing a 3 person scene (this is just a little bit tricky to justify, so I recommend returning to a 2 person scene eventually). This is a great game to do callbacks to previous fun moments throughout the show or even the game (give it a couple of scenes if you want to callback a previous scene from the game).

A suggestion of a foreign language (or made-up one) is grabbed from the audience, as well as the title of a movie that does not exist. 2 Performers are assigned the Actors, who will perform a scene while speaking the foreign language (using gibberish and whatever accent, dialect that is inspired in you). Each Actor is assigned a translator who will be off to the sides. When an Actor gives a line, their translator provides an English translation of that line. Actors Some may consider this role the "less" fun role, because you don't get to say any real words. This is my favorite role in this game. You get to GIVE so many GIFTS. Here are some types of gifts to give: Physicality Use your environment. Use objects. Use body motions. These are all opportunities for your translator to NAME your set-up. If you point into the sky, your translator gets to name what you're pointing at. If you grab an object, your translator gets to name what you are holding/using. There's a huge element of the game Action Replay in this game, so give gifts to your translator to help make the story/world more REAL. Emotions Again, by reacting strongly to something, you give a gift to name the reaction (either directly or with a mis-dub...will talk about under Translator). Be BIG with the emotional direction of the scene. Treat it with elements of a melodrama. Everything that happens should AFFECT you (either subtle or big). Emotions Use a voice, use physicality (more related to a character than the environment). Are you old? What's your gender? What's your attitude? What's your status? You don't have to linger on answering these but play to some of these to again give your translator gifts. Length of Dialogue Sometimes you'll react with a short word or phrase. Sometimes, you'll react with a longer line. These are gifts for the Translator (again, through a direct translation or a mis-dub). Variety in Gibberish If you actually try to vary up your gibberish, rather than just say "Duba Duba Duba" or "Sha La La", then you're giving gifts. Try to not just default to simple gibberish. Use multi-syllabic gibberish words, use different vowel sounds (vowel sounds are VERY emotional, so maybe draw out those sounds more to show emotion), use deliberate repetition (repeat a word a few times as an intentional choice rather than a default gibberish choice). Remember this. Once it's translated, it is now true. Adapt to the changes that the Translators give immediately. Translators The translator is defining what is happening, even though so many things could be happening. But it's your job to bring clarity to the outside world that we are viewing. Have fun and here are some things to think about. Direct Translation This type of translation is defining what you actually see. If you see some angrily point towards the sky and say "Schoo-lerba Tee-loshiky Ly", then you might translate "That tinsel is going to get everywhere!" By doing a direct translation, you are keeping the scene grounded, so aim for this. Make sure you NAME it though. If your partner grabs an object, name it. If they point at something, name it. If they use an emotion, name it. Mis-Dub Mis-dubs are games that you can play in the scene. With these games, you don't want to overplay it too much. Think of the game Duck Duck Goose. If you say 'Goose' all the time, it diminishes the 'Duck'. Here are types that you can play. Length Mis-Dub If your Actor says something long, you might reply with a short word, phrase. Gibberish: "Roreter togac laniler roten legeset gesap yarawe ecane erekimor erepatu. Leh bapiecin si igehok te dibenoy niy ipima ripe he. Tabiwa emit cot onipa ner, ci esewubi des noca je lovatie oto! Acile nurilu pageci, lireton tesaf eriy co eluriro miyefo." Translation: "Sounds good." In my opinion, you can only play this game ONCE, but that's not set in stone. You may be able to perform a rule of 3's by building up with to the above example through slightly shorter statements with short translations. If your Actor says something short, you might reply with a long response. Gibberish: Boski. Translation: I will prove my love for you by traversing the longest oceans, climbing the highest mountains, breathing the thickest air, slurping the hottest soup, binge-watching the longest Netflix series, and by the time I have finished proving my love, hopefully you will love me. Again, in my opinion, you can only play this game ONCE. Emotional Mis-Dub If your Actor gives an emotional line (maybe an angry line), you might translate it as an opposite emotion. Gibberish: *Clearly Angry * "Truska beresh lurginfahla!" Translation: "Thank you for trusting my opinion." You can play this game a few times (I still recommen no more than once or twice), but don't overdo it. If you overuse an emotional mis-dub, then the scene can become confusing. Action Mis-dub If your Actor clearly is using a specific item or doing a specific action, you might swerve them into it being another object/action. If Performer A says angrily: "Menashka der roberangabe" while punching his first into his palm. Translator might say: "I challenge you to Ro Sham Beaux. Allow me to practice with myself first." Again, you can play with this a little more than once. Just don't overdo it. Keep the game & scene balanced. Fusion Scene (Dating)

3 Performers. 2 Performers are onstage and muted. One performer is the voice of god (offstage with microphone in hand). A scenario for a training video is given (how to mow your lawn, decorating for Halloween, lifeguard training, etc.). The voice of god provides voice over instruction on the task, while the 2 performers act it out and react to the instructions. This should be viewed as a cheesy, 1950's style training video. Actors Since this game is silent on your end, you have to be very expressive. There's an element of cheesy expression to compliment the cheesy voiceover. (think a cheesy shrug saying "I don't know!", or a cheesy head nod or thumbs up. Be big and expressive! Cheese it up! Think of yourself as two completely ignorant actors, meaning you don't know what you're doing. The voice of god is guiding you. This allows you to make choices that the voice of god can react to. So if the voice of god asks "Wow, the lawn is getting long and unkempt! What do you think should be done?" Sure, you can shrug, but maybe give the voice of god something to respond to. Eat the grass "No, Lori! That's for the cows to do! It's time to mow the lawn!‚Äù Drink from a flask "Ohhh Kyle! It's only 10 am! It's time to mow the lawn!" Read the newspaper "I hope you're reading the Agriculture section, because it's time to mow the lawn!" Since we are not in the same room, we need to work to not give TOO much for the voice of god. It can be overwhelming if two people are doing different things, or even the same thing. Think about it this way. Are two people required to do the next step? If not, one person can do it, while the other can observe (react, use expressions). So pulling the cord of a lawn mower for example. One person does that task and the other observes. This tells the voice of god to focus on the person pulling the cord. If there is an action that requires two people (like lifting a couch, or pulling a heavy thing via a rope), then great! Two people can simulate that action. Keep the focus balanced. Just like with Sound Effects, there's a balance of giving gifts and receiving them. Let the voice of god guide you, but feel free to give gifts back to the voice of god to justify. It's a balancing act, so don't give TOO much back. But have some creative fun in the scenario that the voice of god is guiding you through. Voice of God The voice of God is a character. Change your voice a bit. It can be your tone (cheery, aggressive, sassy, etc.), or your actual voice (nasally, raspy, light, etc.). Be something that isn't you. You don't have to do the 50's salesman voice that Greg (and I) do, but try something else. A character will help you stay committed to the presentation. You can give focus. You can ask questions to the Actors "Wow! There's a lot of dishes in the sink! What are you two going to do about that?" This give of focus will provide a visual response from the Actors (maybe they both leave the screen, or start breaking the dishes, or start watching TV..."No no no silly! We've got to wash those dishes!" Try the Actors towards the next steps. Don't feel like you need to linger on one thing for too long. Once you've explored the fun and chaos with one thing, move onto the next. If the suggestion is decorating for Halloween, once you've had the actors make a Jack-o-lantern, move onto getting candy ready for the trick-o-treaters, or getting those costumes on. Explore the whole concept rather than just one thing. React to what you see! Based on what you see, you can have some fun. The example from the clip last night that I showed had Ryan putting on underwear, and Greg (Voice of God) said "They're supposed to go inside the pants, Ryan". So Greg reacted to Ryan putting on underwear by naming that Ryan had pants on already (which created a fun visualization for us as the audience). It's pantomime, so name what you see. I played this game as the Voice of God one time, where Bobby and Ben were putting baby powder on a baby's butt, but it looked like to me that they were hammering in a stake, so that's what I called it, and Bobby & Ben did a great job of reacting to what I named. So name STUFF!

games.name: I Can Do Better

setup.description: A group of 6-ish play. Two performers start onstage and do a scene based on a suggestion. At any point during the scene, someone on the side can raise their hand and shout out ‚ÄúI Can Do Better!‚Äù The host asks ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù The cast member says what they can do better in the scene. The host can either accept the action with, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs see it!‚Äù or reject the action. If the host accepts it (which normally happens), the performer jumps onstage and taps out the person they said they can do the better than and immediately does that thing to continue the scene. For example, ‚ÄúI Can Be More Sad!‚Äù Instead of just crying, the performer can do it better by being more dramatic or extreme. Performers can also enter as a third person too without saying ‚ÄúI Can Do Better.‚Äù This game is a heightening game. It‚Äôs also controlled heightening. Don‚Äôt get too absorbed with shouting out I Can Do Better a bunch of times. We don‚Äôt want to lose the scene. Just like in Blind Line, think of Duck Duck Goose. Once the I Can Do Better happens, allow the scene to develop a bit before shouting out another one. That being said, don‚Äôt wait forever to shout out I Can Do Better. You can call it on literally anything. Some examples are: An emotion A reaction An action A character An environment If the scene is bowling, you can say ‚ÄúI Can Do Better!‚Äù ‚ÄúI can be the bowling ball.‚Äù or ‚ÄúI can be the last pin.‚Äù Make sure your ‚ÄúI Can Do Betters‚Äù are used to heighten and not to improve the scene by calling out a mistake or behind-the-scenes concept. Such as, ‚ÄúI can have a better relationship‚Äù or ‚ÄúI can agree in the scene.‚Äù This game is about heightening play and not calling out mistakes.

examples: ‚ÄúI can get there more ridiculously!‚Äù
‚ÄúI can give a better sales pitch!‚Äù
‚ÄúI can have a bigger reaction to the news!‚Äù
In past classes, players were hesitant to shout out ‚ÄúI can do better!‚Äù Thi
Feel free to have a transition in this scene to escalate it to a new moment.
When someone calls out I Can Do Better, do not leave the stage until they tap you out.

setup.description: The host gets a suggestion and the players begin a regular scene. Whenever the non-players choose, they will sing the I Dream of Jeannie theme song. The players on stage pause while the host responds by saying, ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù One of the non-players will make a ‚Äúwish‚Äù and endow one of the players (or all) on stage with a physical trait, vocalization, or for something to happen in the scene. The scene continues and the non-players can keep interjecting later with ‚Äúwishes.‚Äù The host may or may not grant the ‚Äúwish,‚Äù and the ‚Äúwish‚Äù stays as the reality of the scene until it is ‚Äúwished‚Äù away.

games.name: If You Know What I Mean

setup.description: Laugh Out (Soap Opera)

The host gets a suggestion for the game and a few people will start with an opening scene (at least two). At any point a player from the sidelines will be inspired from the scene and yell out, ‚ÄúMeanwhile at ____!‚Äù The player that yelled it out will run on stage and initiate that scene while the previous players run off. Other players can run on stage to support the new scene. The new scene begins with the new location given, which is somewhat tied to the previous scene. This process continues for the rest of the game until the host calls time. This game is similar to what you did in Scene Study (montage), you are world building Remember that adage in improv, ‚Äúif this is true, what else is true?‚Äù Apply it here as you build the world! Think of interrupting the scene like Freeze or I Can Do Better, the scenes should only be about 5 - 15 secs long. As a sideline player, try to associate anything from the previous scene. Here‚Äôs a silly example: Rainforest (wished we had an umbrella) > Umbrella Factory (umbrellas made of ostrich feathers > Ostrich Farm

games.name: My Movie

setup.description: Players stand in a line with host in front. Get suggestion of a letter or film genre.

rules: Host conducts players to say "My Movie, My Movie, My Movie"
Host points at player who names a made-up movie title using suggestion
When audience/host likes a title (indicated by "oooo"), player gives tagline
If host likes it, they say "let's see it!" and players do short scene
Host calls scene by walking back to middle
Get new suggestion or continue with same

setup.description: 2 Performers (Performer A & B) begin onstage and are given a suggestion of a location (something a little broader, since different characters and different situations can occur). The other performers are offstage (stop video). In this game, only questions can be used in the scene. When a statement, hesitation, or repetition (like saying the same question back to your partner too much) occurs, the host will BUZZ the performer out and Performer C will come in and continue the game. Performer C has the choice of taking on the same character and continuing the story, or they can reset and come in with a new idea. Whoever enters after an elimination gets the first line. This game is MEANT to make you screw up. But it also thrives on the mistakes/eliminations. If you play this game TOO well, it can get boring. This doesn‚Äôt mean you have to forcefully throw yourself out. Here are ways to play the game that will cause more natural/real eliminations. Go faster. Don‚Äôt think about what you‚Äôre going to say, just jump into the next question. A quicker speaking tempo will cause more mistakes (which again...are GOOD). If your partner asks a question like ‚ÄúDid you eat all of the sandwiches?‚Äù instead of thinking, just start with an interrogative immediately and figure out the rest once you say it. ‚ÄúHowwww many are missing?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhhhheeere is the dang dog?‚Äù Vary up the type of questions. You can create a personal rule for yourself that says ‚ÄúIf your scene partner says a question that begins with ‚ÄúWhy...‚Äù, you can‚Äôt say ‚ÄúWhy...‚Äù There are plenty of other interrogative words ‚ÄúWhat, Who, When, Where, How‚Äù and other words that start scenes ‚ÄúDo you...?‚Äù ‚ÄúHave you....?‚Äù ‚ÄúWill you....‚Äù Even ending your sentence with a questioning inflection can work. Try again??? I might eliminate you on those types of sentences, but again, that‚Äôs not BAD...that‚Äôs GOOD! Don‚Äôt deliver your lines in a sterile tone. Be a character. I find myself making mistakes (again...GOOD) more naturally if I play a strong character, because I no longer overanalyze the game as my own self. A giant blob monster wouldn‚Äôt be super focused on just saying questions, but I would, because I know the rules of the game, and I‚Äôm going to follow those rules, right? Don‚Äôt always be so logical. I‚Äôm not saying just say something random. The questions should still have a connection, but you can also have a more off-the-wall or at the very least SPECIFIC choice in your question.That will cause more natural mistakes. The scenes shouldn‚Äôt be based in confusion. In short, don‚Äôt be confused. Confusing scenes suck and are hard to be in, so even though questions are the primary tool of this game (and you always hear in improv, don‚Äôt ask questions), we can still be informed characters with our questions. So, try to make every question you deliver have some nugget of information. Imagine you know the person you‚Äôre with, or at the very least have an immediate connection with them. Here are some examples of what to avoid and what to do. DON‚ÄôT SAY: ‚ÄúWhere are we?‚Äù SAY: ‚ÄúWhere is the Marriott?‚Äù Extra nugget: say that line paranoid/scared while mime driving a car. DON‚ÄôT SAY: ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù SAY: ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt you Daniel Day Lewis?‚Äù Extra nugget: say awestruck while pointing or hands on cheek. DON‚ÄôT SAY: ‚ÄúWhat are we doing?‚Äù SAY: ‚ÄúIs eating lunch before swimming wise?‚Äù Extra nugget: while licking your fingers, or while cutting into a ribeye. Use EMOTIONS. Even if you say, ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù say it with surprise, fear, anger, curiosity, etc. Add something to your delivery. Be OKAY messing up. This is how the game works. Go out BIG. The audience is waiting for an elimination. When the scene starts, they are silently doing a drum roll to themselves. Don‚Äôt leave them waiting too long. So be BOLD, be BIG, especially when you are going OUT. Go out on an upward moment, not a downer because you lost the game... :( Being eliminated is fun, so have fun with it. (Don‚Äôt get frustrated, get excited).
Stunt Double

games.name: Superheroes

setup.description: 4 Performers Needed. A simple but urgent situation is grabbed from the audience, and the suggestion of the 1st Superhero. The game starts with the first performer on stage committing to that suggested superhero and then discovering the situation. One at a time, each performer enters. When performer B enters, performer A endows them as a hero. Performer B immediately becomes overcome with that character, and they both have an interaction. Performer C enters, and Performer B endows. Then Performer D enters, and Performer C endows. The scene ends after all 4 are onstage. ENDOWMENT: This game is about endowing your scene partner with a gift of a superhero that doesn't exist. The endowments can range from emotional-based, physical-based, pop culture-based, character-based, but the overall theme is these are impractical superheroes that would never exist. Un-superheroes who think they are superheroes. It's helpful to play with range when endowing. For example, if the first endowment is "Road Rage Man", that is emotional based. So, the next one might be pop culture or character based, such as "Super Sloth". Typically, it's best to end with something physical, such as, "Does-The-Worm-Excessively-Lad". This helps add a strong exclamation mark to the game and can help you find an ending. HAVE/SAY/DO: This is a technique that Paul Vaillancourt came up with in regard to defining your character, in this case a superhero. When you are endowed as a superhero, think of what you have, what you say, and what you do.

examples: Have: You have a dixie cup of punch that you hold in front of your body.
Say: "I'll be, uh, over here *gestures to the wall* if you need me."
Do: You cling to the backwall, like a chameleon.
Have can be objects/props/costume, but it can also be your unique powers.
Say can include wordplay, puns. It can include catchphrases, too (Spiderman says "my Spidey senses are tingling"
Do is where physicality comes into play. Don't just say/have, show us through the "do."

COMMIT! When you are endowed, immediately take on the traits and don't be afraid of looking silly! Think of how you physically become this character, if it changes your voice, and let it inspire what you say. If your character was "Dad Joke Man", well yeah, you'll tell corny dad jokes to subdue your enemy, but that affects your personality, your voice, and your physically! Don't just say corny jokes! Become a corny dad!
FLOW! This game works with timing in mind. This is short form, so we don't want to wait too long, but we also don't want to race pass ideas and fun.

When performer one is onstage. Become the character during "calm times". The situation hasn't happened yet. Drop a line, use physicality...what is this hero doing when nothing bad is happening, what is their routine? Then SHOW the urgent situation happening! Greg Proops always drops in a silly Superhero exclamation line: "Great Casear's Ghost!" "Holy Macaroni & Cheese!" or it can be something related to your character...it's almost like your catchphrase. Then reference the urgent situation, and then the next hero will join.

When each hero enters, quickly endow them. "Thank goodness you're here ________". Before we move on, we want to see how this hero affects the group dynamic. How does this hero change and affect the other hero(es).

End with Ordered Chaos! When all heroes are onstage, yes, it will feel a little chaotic. But we just need to go back to basics with Give & Take of focus and Yes And. Take is especially powerful, but don't just take with your voice, take with your body. It also helps to start a sentence with an attention-grabbing line or word. Before saying "We can save the town with my air dryer hands!", say "Herooooes!....We can save the town with my air dryer hands!" Heroooooes, works as an attention grabber, so focus will now be directed to you.

Also, come together on SOMETHING. Don't be 4 separate entities. You are all the Avengers, Fantastic Four, or the X-Men. You all work in tandem, even if you're drastically separate identities. Maybe come together on a solution using everybody's power (just do it now, don't talk about doing it), maybe come together on a group pose or group catchphrase (All for 1, and 1 for all!). Come together to limit the chaos or at the very least, control it.

Have FUN! This game is short. Go ALL OUT! The game will be over, and you'll never get to play that hero again. So, savor the moment. Not just of your character but of your partners' characters. Let yourself live and let them live. No confused, awkward looks. You're a hero, BE IT!

categories.name: Guessing Games
categories.description: Games where performers must guess information

setup.description: A guessing game that uses pantomime and gibberish, one guesser, and five clue-givers. First, send the guesser outside. Then, gather 5 suggestions from the audience, here are some suggested gets: A famous person or character A common pairing (knife and fork, salt and vinegar, Abbott and Costello) A well-known story (Three Little Pigs, Garden of Eden, It‚Äôs a Wonderful Life) A recognizable location (Statue of Liberty, France, Pyramids of Giza) A historical event Once gathered, the clue givers will decide their order and then call the player back in.
