Using pantomime and gibberish, the first clue giver communicates the first suggestion. Once the guesser confirms they understand it (or needs to move on), then the second clue giver jumps on stage to start giving the second suggestion alongside the first clue giver. Each time it seems as if the guesser has understood the suggestion, the next clue giver enters and, with those already on stage, communicates the next suggestion. This keeps going until all five clue givers are working together. When the guesser believes they understand the final suggestion, the host will pause the game to call the guesser forward. The 5 clue givers will then form a tableau to remind the audience and the guesser of their suggestion. The guesser will make their guess loud and proud, and whether or not they are correct, the fifth clue giver will run off stage for the 4 clue givers to form the fourth tableau. This keeps going until the guesser gets down to the first suggestion. The entering clue giver takes the lead on their suggestion, the other clue givers on stage support and become what‚Äôs needed The five suggestions can be any variety, but they should be designed from smallest to largest

The host sends one player out of the room to be the guesser and gets a list of 10 or more stories, video games, movies, television shows, etc. The host then calls the guesser back in, and sets a certain amount of time (can range from 3 minutes to 5 minutes). Using only pantomime and gibberish, the clue givers will put the guesser into the story, in the order that was suggested by the audience. The clue givers must try their best to make the guesser the main character of each suggestion. Once the guesser thinks they know it, they will step forward and guess. Right or wrong, the team moves on to the next item on the list. This continues until all items are guessed or time runs out.The host will then recap all the ones they did not get, and the ones they did get.
Celebrity Uber (Taxi)

games.name: Chain Murder

setup.description: This guessing game requires 4 players, and can be done with an audience member as the fourth person. 1 player stays while the rest of the team leaves the room. The host will get the following suggestions from the audience: a location, an occupation not related to the location, and a murder weapon that normally wouldn‚Äôt be used as a weapon (LOW). The goal is to give all clues, 1 player to the next (like a game of telephone), within 3 minutes. Location: McDonald‚Äôs Occupation: Dentist Weapon: Rubber Chicken Once all clues are gathered, 1 player that was sent outside will run in. The first player will then use pantomime and gibberish to convey all three clues. Once the second player believes they know the murder weapon, they will use it to murder the first player, and the audience shouts ‚Äúthey‚Äôre dead!‚Äù Then the next player runs in, and the second player will convey their clues to the next person and will ultimately be killed by the third player. This repeats with the fourth player. The host will then ask all players to rise from the dead and starting with the fourth player, ask them what they thought the location, occupation and murder weapon was. If the fourth player is wrong on one of them, they will go to the next player to see if they know what it is. You have 3 minutes total for the clue giving and guessing, so it‚Äôs ideally broken down like this: 1st and 2nd Players: 90 seconds (30 seconds each clue) 2nd and 3rd Players: 60 seconds (20 seconds each clue) 3rd and 4th Players: 30 seconds (10 seconds each clue) As the clue giver, you want the guesser to be the occupation. Similar to 5 Things when setting up the activity, you want to set up the guesser to be the person with the job. For the dentist, I would pantomime and gibberish my tooth being in pain and needing to be removed. Avoid parroting what the previous person gave you as a clue. If someone did the golden arches and did the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Loving It‚Äù jingle for McDonald‚Äôs, then find something else that you could give a clue for McDonald‚Äôs. I would be a clown making a cheeseburger. Don‚Äôt be too fixated on getting things right. I would rather you have fun! It‚Äôs about the journey and not the destination. It can be even funnier when you get it wrong because the audience is in on the joke and can see the trainwreck from the beginning, especially in a game of telephone! Don‚Äôt repeat a wrong guess. If you thought the location was Burger King, but the previous player said it and it was wrong, say something else, even if you 100% thought it was Burger King. Crime Story (Principal‚Äôs Office) A guessing game. One person (the criminal) leaves the room, while the other players gather the suggestion of crime, motive, and accomplice. The crime is not a real crime, the motive is not connected to the crime at all, and the accomplice is a celebrity, cartoon character, historical figure, etc.

examples: Crime: They watched a movie
Motive: Because they were hungry for spaghetti
Accomplice: They did it with Robert DeNiro.

The game is played like a scene in an interrogation room, where the criminal (guesser) has to guess the entire crime. Clue givers must drop subtle hints to get the guesser to correctly say the crime. Hints come in the form of puns, setting the scene, and describing the scenario. Clue givers cannot say any of the words in the crime: so you can't say "watched" or "movie," you must lead the guesser up to say it first. If the guesser does say a word that is part of the clue, then you may use it. The game is over once the guesser gets all three clues, or the host calls time.
Clue givers:
Start out subtle (puns are usually the most subtle), build up to more obvious clues.
Pick a strong character (good cop, bad cop generally start, if there are three clue givers, someone can come in as a lawyer, another cop, a lover, a fellow criminal, etc).
A third person can enter and leave as an additional clue giver, sometime during the second clue or the first clue if the guesser is struggling.
Be sure to find a reason to leave as the third person in the middle so it doesn‚Äôt get too hectic.

Giving clues is like climbing a ladder. Get the guesser to say each word one at a time: get him/her to say hungry, then get him/her to say spaghetti. Positive reinforcement! If they say HUNGRY! Say "YES, you were hungry..but what did you want is the question!" Saying yes tells the guesser if they are on the right track.
When you give clues, make sure to leave room for the guesser to speak. It‚Äôs like a ping pong match, share the focus.
Guesser:
Pick a strong character! It's a guessing game, but still play the scene.
Always throw out guesses, even if you have no idea! If you say HUNGRY and they positively reinforce you, keep saying HUNGRY in your guess. Climb that ladder with the clue givers.
By constantly throwing out guesses (I call ‚Äúactive guessing‚Äù), you are subtly informing your clue givers where your train of thought is and then they can pivot with their clues.
Gauge the time. If you know the answer right off the bat, play a little "dumb". The audience loves the struggle.

I was in a game where we had 30 seconds left and they said ‚ÄúShake it Off.‚Äù I immediately knew it was Taylor Swift as my accomplice, but I played dumb to build up the tension and eventually end the game strong at nearly the last possible moment.
When you‚Äôre ready to guess the last clue (the accomplice), say the whole thing: crime, motivation and accomplice.
‚ÄúFine, I‚Äôll admit it! I was watching a movie because I was hungry for spaghetti and I did it with Robert DeNiro!‚Äù

setup.description: This is a guessing game with one guesser and three clue givers. While the guesser is outside, the guessers each get a suggestion for a character. These can be anything from objects, high school cliques, occupations, celebrities, fictional characters, historical figures, etc. The guesser returns and asks 3 rounds of questions to the three bachelors/bachelorettes. The clue givers answer the questions while dropping subtle hints on who they are. Once the 3 rounds conclude, the guesser guesses the two he/she did not choose, and the person he/she did choose! The host will help facilitate and give additional clues if needed, or make quips! Clue Givers You get to choose your suggestion, so pick something you're confident with. If you know pop culture well, pick a celebrity, musician, etc. If you aren't too versed in actual people, be an object or occupation. You can even be specific with what you ask for: "Can I get a Disney villain?" "Can I get a High School clique?" Be subtle at first. If they can easily guess who you are by the first round, then you're being too obvious. Be specific. If the question is, "Where would you take me on our first date?" avoid giving a one-word answer. Take the audience on a journey into your character. Give your character a personality! Even if it is something that you wouldn‚Äôt normally associate with a personality. If you are a spatula, then what type of spatula are you? Commit hard to your character, even if you don't know a lot about it. Embody the character even when the spotlight isn‚Äôt on you, avoid going to a neutral stance when you‚Äôre not talking. Plus, it helps you maintain that character when you‚Äôre ready to speak again. Guesser Feel free to be a character yourself! My go-to character in this is a Southern Belle or a Prospector looking for love. Ask fairly simple questions that are open-ended. Some good questions are "where would you take me on our first date?", "what activity can we do together to bond?" "What is your favorite place to be alone?" You can also preface each question with a little bit about your character..."Bachelor #1, the last date I went on was to the DMV, where's some place exciting you would take me?" Ask the bachelors in rotating order. Question 1 to Bachelors 1, 2, then 3. Question 2 to 2, 3, 1. Question 3 to 3, 1, 2. This makes the game fair, so the same person isn't answering first every time. When guessing, start with someone you're pretty confident you know the answer to, then the one you're not so sure about, then end with one you are 100% confident in (or the most confident in). This makes it so the game ends on a pop! When you guess, preface it by naming the bachelor number you are guessing for. "You know...I don't think I can choose bachelor #2, because I'm allergic to fish...Aquaman! Be confident with your guesses! Even if you have no idea who someone is, give a guess as if you are 100% certain that you do know. Some of the most fun in short form is being wrong, because it gives us a chance to see how your mind connects different dots to get to a completely new idea!
Evil Lair (Hostage Negotiator)

Two groups of improvisers leave the room. The audience suggests a genre (a real genre like romantic comedy) for each group and then brainstorms a complete list (5 things) of common clich√©s from each genre. One set of improvisers returns, is given the genre, and creates a scene, trying to incorporate as many clich√©s as they can think of. Someone not in the scene ticks the list of audience-provided clich√©s as they‚Äôre used, the audience is encouraged to clap any time they spot a suggested clich√©. The second set of improvisers return, get a different genre, and create their own scene with the clich√©s. Whichever group incorporated the most clich√©s wins. Alternatively, this can be done with one genre and both teams competing to get the most clich√©s from the same genre.

One guesser is sent out of the room while one player is designated the boss and two others as the coworkers. The guesser will guess what activity made them late, why they did it and who is their alibi. As the host is gathering this information, the players will be writing this down to later recap for the audience (and for when clue givers forget what the answers are). The game begins when the guesser returns back in and the guesser will have about three minutes to guess everything. The boss will drop subtle verbal hints, while the coworkers will only use pantomime to show the clues. The boss may occasionally turn around to catch the coworkers in some awkward situation, which the coworkers will then justify what they‚Äôre doing. The game is over when time is up or the guesser completely states all three clues.

tips: The premise of this game is that you‚Äôre late for work and you‚Äôre making up your excuse on the spot with the help of your coworkers. Once you realize you‚Äôre in trouble, start looking at your coworkers behind your boss and look to them for help.
Project and have fun with the struggle, you and the boss are going to be auditorily filling the space as the game goes on.

The fun of this game is always the journey with guessing. If you‚Äôre unsure with your guess and you know it‚Äôs wrong, still say it with confidence. The audience knows the answer, so they get enjoyment when they can be like, ‚ÄúHaha, no you‚Äôre wrong!‚Äù
Listen to the time cues shouted out by the host, you generally want to give 1 minute per guess.
If the guesser is still not getting it after time is winding down, don‚Äôt be afraid to be really obvious with the clues.
Boss
Give subtle verbal clues at first, as the fun of it is mainly from the pantomime given by the coworkers
Once per section, the boss should look back and catch the coworkers in place with their pantomime. You‚Äôre providing a gift for the coworkers to justify whatever silly position they are in.
You‚Äôre leading the conversation to make sure the guesser is on the right track with their guesses. If they‚Äôre venturing too far off, correct them.
Have fun with the jerk boss character, you‚Äôre the comedic foil!
Coworkers
Start pantomiming once you see the guesser look towards you like they‚Äôre ready to start fibbing their way into an excuse.
Similar to HSN, Playground Insults and 5 or 6 Things, establish the scene to provide better context for your clue.
When the boss turns around, freeze or continue doing your motion (do NOT revert to a normal stance). It‚Äôs fun to see what justification you give to whatever you‚Äôre doing.
Find moments when you can make a big noise to get the boss‚Äôs attention to turn around. If you find yourselves in a silly moment, prompting them can yield fun results!
Stage Picture: make sure you‚Äôre both seen by the audience and by the guesser.

setup.description: One performer is the Host of a party (the Guesser). The other three performers secretly receive a prompt for a character (usually something kind of bizarre). The host begins the game by doing a quick line to set up the fact that they are having a party. A doorbell will ring and the Guest 1 will come in. They will give some clues (physical/verbal). The doorbell will ring again, and Guest 2 will come in and give clues, then the doorbell will ring one more time, and finally Guest 3 will come on. Through clues, the Host will try to guess who each performer is. Once the guess is correct, a buzzer will ring, and that performer will leave. Party Guests I won't get into too many tips for playing the characters, because I've already talked about that in games like Let's Make a Date & Weird Newscasters. Refer to those tips from previous emails (just scroll down). Main thing is to COMMIT and not just limit yourself to verbal clues (be physical). Here are some tips though for the flow of the game. When you first enter the party, the full focus is on YOU. Use this time to truly become the character. Once the doorbell rings, you will have light focus. Which means that you can still be the character but think of it more in the background. You can still do subtle physical activities, because the Guesser will still be looking at you at times. In short, don't go neutral, you're still in the game. Once all Party Guests are out, now we are going to have a balance of give and take (mostly take). Which means, you need to get in there to give clues. Don't just let the conversation be between the Host and Party Guest #3. Take, take, take! Although the number 1 priority is to truly commit to the character, a side priority is to aim your clues around reality (being at a party). So, if you're playing the "The Titanic sinking", instead of just screaming "ICEBERG!!!!"....maybe scream "ICEBERG salad! My favorite, I am on a diet you know?" Try to keep your clues within the context of the attending a party, so the game doesn't become disconnected. Party Host When the game begins, establish the reality a bit. What type of party are you planning? Are you prepping appetizers? Are you setting up a game? Also keep doing it, up until you hear the doorbell. Imagine, you are last minute getting everything ready in a rush. As the Party Host, YOU are the glue. You are keeping this party together. So, stay strong as the host. A lot of the comedy comes from a bizarre character entering and after they provide their bizarre clues, you say something grounded around the party, "Can I get you some artichoke dip?" So just like the guests, you also need to stay in character! Try to avoid guessing right away. I prefer all guests to arrive before you start guessing. Also, try to not be confused by these weird people at this party. Even though this is a guessing game, imagine that you KNOW these people. You can 100% still be puzzled by what they are doing, but imagine you knew what you were getting into when inviting these people.

games.name: Press Conference

setup.description: One performer is holding a press conference as a CHARACTER who is announcing SOMETHING. They do not know who they are and what they are announcing. The other 3 performers are reporters who ask questions trying to clue the presenter into their endowments. The game is ended by the host who asks the presenter to guess. Guesser The notes here are somewhat similar to News Flash, since the concept is similar. The guesser's job is to be specific with their responses. The comedy comes from the juxtaposition between the responses and the actual Character/Announcement. The audience is in on the joke. The game starts with a simple introduction by the guesser, welcoming everybody to the event. Thank you for joining me here today. This has been weighing on me for a long time and I'm relieved to finally share this with you. Notice this line is meant to conclude the announcement and then questions come. It's as though the previous line was the announcement that the guesser is trying to guess. Don't worry about guessing. The game will end and the host will ask who you are and what you're announcing. You can drop a hint that clues the reporters in that you know one of the endowments. If your character is Santa Claus, then you might drop a reference to elves. When you do that, then the reporters should pivot to giving clues towards the announcement. Reporters Reporters ask questions when they are called on. Raise your hand when you're ready. When you are called on for the 1st time, I recommend naming yourself and who you represent

examples: It doesn't have to be a joke or a clue. It just helps contribute to the reality. ‚ó¶ Similar to News Flash, the first few questions can be simple and open ended. After that you can give subtle clues, puns, play-on-words, etc.
You can also play with being actual reporters
A few examples:
Hold and use your notepad
Scribble frantically when something big is given
Give a vocal response to something gossipy
Take a quick picture.

setup.description: The host gets suggestions of three unrelated made up song titles, then gets either a regular scene suggestion or the title of a never before produced musical. While the host is explaining the game, the players will quietly choose which song they would like to sing in the scene. The scene starts after a recap of the song titles. The players will then play the scene and find ways to call for their song by confidently saying their song title out to the audience (and sound booth or pianist). The scene ends when the host calls it or after all three songs are sung.

Performer A plays the Bartender, and Performer B plays someone who has a problem or feels an emotion about something (in love with something, scared of something). The problem or feeling is a suggestion provided by the audience. Performer B enters the bar (set with few props). The song begins playing immediately and after some patter to begin the song, Performer B sings a verse or two about what they feel. Performer A sings a response that either helps solve the problem (if there is one) or heightens the problem/feeling. Typically, this game is done with 2 or 3 separate performers as the patrons, separated by the host grabbing new suggestions. Therefore, the songs should be short and sweet. Similar to Hoedown, this is more of a verse-based game with no chorus, since choruses can take extra time to establish.

games.name: Beastie Rap

setup.description: Two groups of 3-4 take the stage and place themselves on opposite sides of the stage with a chair in front of them. One performer from each group sits in their chair, and a name is received from the audience. The singers will go back and forth with lines that rhyme with the received name, but the singers are not allowed to say the rhyme, they are leading their posse to say it.

examples: Performer A: I know this dude and his name is...
Posse A: GREG!
Performer B: He stands real strong on only one...
Posse B: LEG!
Performer A: He‚Äôs a pro at cracking an...
Posse A: EGG!
Performer B: You want some breakfast, you‚Äôll have to...
Posse B: BEG!
Anytime there‚Äôs a mistake, new performers rotate in. Mistakes come in the form of
hesitating, falling off the beat, or repeating a word that‚Äôs been said.
This game is based off the rap group Beastie Boys, and here are some of their songs:
No Sleep Till Brooklyn
(You Gotta) Fight For Your Right (To Party)
Brass Monkey
Paul Revere (We use this instrumental in the show)
Paul Revere - Instrumental (If you want to practice on your own)
Da Doo Ron Ron (Rap Rap)
1st person: I met him on a Monday and his name was Bill
All: Da Doo Ron Ron Ron, Da Doo Ron Ron
2nd person: His tank was empty so I gave it a fill
All: Da Doo Ron Ron Ron, Da Doo Ron Ron
All (Except 3rd): Da doo do do, yea!
3rd person: We pushed it up the hill
All (Except 3rd): Da doo do do, yea!
3rd person: I felt really ill
All (Except 3rd): Da doo do, yea!
3rd person: So he gave me a pill
All: Da Doo Ron Ron Ron, Da Doo Ron Ron
4th person: He gave me a pickle, said it was a dill
All: Da Doo Ron Ron Ron, Da Doo Ron Ron
5th person: I was super hungry so I stuffed it in my mouth!
Host: Wait a minute, that doesn‚Äôt rhyme! (5th player is eliminated)
Da Doo Rap Rap is the same, but with a ‚ÄúSay Whaaat‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúDa do do do, yeah!‚Äù
The game will keep going until a player hesitates, falls off the meter or repeats a word that has been said previously.
Once you hear a name, immediately start creating a list of words that rhyme with the name within your head.

If you can‚Äôt think of any words that rhyme, then that means you can use any word* (Please keep it appropriate) you want! Fail big, go out on top by using a word that absolutely doesn‚Äôt rhyme at all like banana! The audience is expecting a rhyme so it can be funny to subvert those expectations with a line that keeps to the story but doesn‚Äôt rhyme.

Super secret extra credit points are given if you can keep a consistent narrative going throughout the song. This can be extremely challenging, but it can provide fun opportunities for you to throw yourself out in ways that keep with the story but don‚Äôt rhyme.
Similar to games like story, if we‚Äôve gone for a while with no eliminations, find a way to throw yourself out so we can start fresh!

setup.description: 3 Performers take the stage as a Doo Wop trio. The host gets the suggestion of single name and a way for that person to die (nothing real, more impractical). The Doo Wop trio sings a song lamenting the loss of the suggested person.

Greatest Hits 4 Performers are onstage, with 2 seated on one side as the hosts and 2 are standing on the other side of the stage as the singers. A suggestion of an unlikely topic for a compilation CD is gathered from the audience, and the disc jockeys host a radio show where they first banter and then introduce songs from the CD. Once a song is introduced, the singers immediately sing that song. Once the song ends, we return to the hosts who banter and then introduce the next song. Typically, the game contains 3 songs total. The hosts can introduce songs by setting up the genre of song and then saying the song title.

Two teams are formed (usually 3 performers each). One team plays a musical group auditioning for American Idol, and the other team plays the judges. A suggestion of a title is grabbed from the audience. Team 1 begins by holding a note that shows the conclusion of their song. The judges one at a time give ‚Äúfeedback‚Äù to each of the other singers. The ‚Äúfeedback‚Äù is an endowment of something they did in the song. Once all judges have given their feedback, we see the full song performed in addition to the endowments played. Once the song ends, the roles switch.

3-4 players perform an improvised scene based on a suggestion. At any point, the host can shout ‚ÄúNAME! Inner Song-a-logue!‚Äù That performer sings a song based on their inner thoughts. When the song ends, they immediately spring back into reality and continue the scene.

games.name: Irish Drinking Song

setup.description: 4 Performers form a line onstage, and the host grabs a suggestion of the theme for the Irish Drinking Song. The music plays (track available in Practice Folder), and the cast sings 4 sections. Each section has 2 verses, following the ABCB rhyming structure.

examples: Performer 1: This is a singing game (A)
Performer 2: We played in the class (B)
Performer 3: It was really fun (C)
Performer 4: It had a little sass (B)
Performer 1: It can be a little hard (A)
Performer 2: But we have to keep it simple (B)
Performer 3: If we make it difficult (C)
Performer 4: It‚Äôll pop like a pimple (B)
Everyone: Ohhh, aye-dee-di-dee-di-dee-di-dee-di-dee-di-dee-di
We now go into the next section, but Person 2 starts the first line. The 3rd section is started by Person 3, and the 4th section by Person 4.

games.name: Lounge Lizards

setup.description: Rap Battle (Rhyme Line) Two groups of 3-4 take the stage and place themselves on opposite sides of the stage. Each group is assigned a group of BLANK (ex. a group of Clowns, a group of Yogis, etc.). A rap backing track is played and both groups will go back and forth exchanging disses toward each other.

examples: Clown:
Yo, you think you‚Äôre clever, you‚Äôre about to have a frown
Because you can‚Äôt match the pace of this clown.
You‚Äôre going down not later but soon,
I‚Äôm gonna twist you up like an animal balloon.
OOOOOOOH!
Yogi:
Relax, you‚Äôre so angry you‚Äôre seething
I think you could use a little deep breathing.
And I think you‚Äôre definitely a clown at dissin‚Äô
There‚Äôs no way you can match my Warrior Position.
OOOOOOOH!
At this point, the mics are given to two new rappers. The game ends with the audience voting on who won the Rap Battle.

setup.description: 4 Performers take the stage and stand off to the side. The host grabs a suggestion, usually in the form of an urgent situation, or even a well-known movie or story. A rapping track is played and the cast performs an improvised scene, completely in rap lyrics.

Players will do a neutral scene and at any moment the host can interrupt the scene by calling a player‚Äôs name, saying the last line they said, then ‚ÄúSING IT!‚Äù That player will now sing a song based on the suggested line, which is usually the chorus/thesis of the song they are singing. When they‚Äôre done, they will finish the song strong and go back into the scene. Other players can support during the song or even make it a duet or a group song.
3 performers get on stage and are given a song title from the audience. The performers operate as one entity and sing one word at a time.

games.name: Boo Yay

setup.description: Two players step up and the host will get a non-controversial topic for both players to ‚Äúdebate.‚Äù One player will be assigned to say positive things about the topic, which will elicit a ‚Äúyay‚Äù response from the audience. The other player will say negative things about the topic, which will elicit a ‚Äúboo‚Äù response from the audience. Both players will go back-and-forth until one of them hesitates, says something that doesn‚Äôt make sense or gets the opposite reaction, or the host calls it to move the game along.

examples: Player 1: Water keeps you hydrated!
YAY!
Player 2: Drinking water makes me go to the bathroom!
BOO!
Player 1: Pools are full of water and they cool you off!
YAY!
Player 2: You can drown.
Boo!
Call-In Radio

setup.description: The host will ask the audience for a well-known fairy tale, then ask the volunteer to briefly explain it. After the interview, the players begin to host a news show. One player takes the lead anchor position and someone will be in the studio with them. The lead anchor will introduce a major event that has happened in the world of the fairy tale, that is a new development than the already established fairytale. For example, the anchor can discuss the housing shortage in the world of 3 Little Pigs. The lead anchor will then endow the player next to them with a character, and that player embodies that character. After some back and forth, the lead anchor will throw it to the other players out in the ‚Äúfield.‚Äù That field reporter will then endow another player a character. The segment will eventually return back to the studio where the lead anchor will again endow the player in the studio of a new character. This will then go back out to the field for one final segment. Alternatively, these sections could be sports, economy, weather, etc.

games.name: Game-o-Matic

setup.description: The host will start by getting two initials from the audience. The host will then stall time for about 30 seconds while the players think of an entirely new game, both the name and how it‚Äôs played. The host will clear the stage and players one at a time will present the name of the game and succinctly describe how it‚Äôs played to the audience (just one or two sentences, you can give more details if your game gets chosen).

examples: Game: Epic Rap

Description: Players will be doing a scene and then the host can yell ‚ÄúEpic Rap,‚Äù then music will play and the players will start rapping. The host will then yell, ‚ÄúWord!‚Äù and they will then stop rapping and go back to the scene.
Game: Hey Girl (or Guy)
Description: This is a pun-based game where our players will come out and pretend they‚Äôre hitting on you at a bar by giving you a pick up line based on a suggestion.

Once all players have said their name, the host will come back out and help lead the audience in deciding which game gets chosen. You will then say the name of your game again, then one short blurb about the game. When voting, just say the name of the game. If your game gets chosen, then YOU now become the host of this game, complete with explaining the game and time calls.
If you can‚Äôt think of an entirely new game and premise, just reskin an existing game. ‚ÄúHey Girl‚Äù is basically ‚ÄúI Kissed A‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúI like my lover‚Ä¶‚Äù
It can be a host-interrupt game like New Choice or Forward - Reverse a replay game like Replay at Bernie‚Äôs or Eliminator Replay, a guessing game like Crime Story, etc.
Do not repeat words already used in the title of games. If someone already used ‚Äúepic,‚Äù well now your game is ‚Äúexcited‚Äù or another e- word.
Have fun with this game, there is a chance it‚Äôs a failure because it can be a game you‚Äôve never played before. But you‚Äôll also never play it again!

setup.description: An idea of a problem is received from the audience. The performers receive a box of random objects. They then begin hosting an infomercial to help solve the problem that was given. Every so often they bring a new object out and justify it into the infomercial. Don't worry about the props at first. Set up the reality. What's your show's name? Who are you? What are your names? What are your personalities? Banter with each other for a bit. Watch Ryan and Colin in any game based on addressing a camera in some type of show. They are great at this. Let the intro transition into the problem and how you're going to solve it I think it's best to have a leading statement or question before you bring out the objects. Let's demonstrate how this problem affects everyday Americans. Our competitors use this to handle the problem POORLY. So how can we help you solve this problem? The objects can sometimes be manipulated, so don't treat them as static, make them dynamic. The objects can be representative of other things; a graph, a 3D demonstration, a product, etc. SELL! SELL! SELL! Imagine you've done this infomercial before. Your characters KNOW what they are doing. Don't lose your energy or get confused. Maintain that strong character that you had before you grab your first object throughout.

Players stand on stage, forming a half circle around the host. The host gets an object from the audience that you wouldn‚Äôt really need a manual to use the product. Once received, the host will start pointing at the players to provide the introductory chapter of this product, which is a nice time to showcase that this product is no ordinary version of it, but it‚Äôs special! The host will point at a player and they must begin talking. Once the host moves their hand away, the player stops talking and then the next player pointed at will pick up the sentence and sometimes the word. Player 1: This pencil is special because it does not write with lead, it‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 2: (host points now at them) ‚Äìwrites with blood from Zues, the Greek‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 3: (host points now at them) ‚ÄìGod of Thunder. OR Player 1: To properly lubricate this pencil, please use wa‚Äì Player 2: ‚Äìtermelons. Take the seeds from the fruit and see it shar‚Äì Player 3: ‚Äìpen as the grind rubs against it. Eventually, the host will get new chapters that can be found in an instruction manual. Like maintenance, Q&A, warranty, etc. A round or chapter is over once someone hesitates, repeats, or fails to pick up what was previously said. The losing player may either be eliminated or receive an endowment. You are the expert on this product! Have that sophisticated, expert stance, voice, etc. If you say things that don‚Äôt make sense in the real world, that‚Äôs okay because this is a unique product that you and your fellow players only know! Remember the details previously said, even if they were from earlier rounds. Callbacks are always fun! LISTEN! Also, focus your attention on the host because they may be pointing to you soon. Look with your eyes, listen with your ears. Not all hosts do this, but typically we try to signal that we‚Äôre pointing to you next by making intense eye contact. Don‚Äôt worry about messing up! Just like What Are You Doing and Try That on for Size, this game needs people to fail. Find ways to dive if the rounds go on for too long.

This game is best played with three players. The players will line up in a row and can only speak one letter or word at a time. The host will start by asking the audience for an easy word to spell, like CAT. The players must say the word together at the same time, then spell it one at a time, starting with the player on stage right (house left). ALL PLAYERS: CAT Player 1: C Player 2: A Player 3: T ALL PLAYERS: CAT The host will then ask for a follow up on it, such as using it in a sentence, the origin of the word, definition, etc. The words will gradually ramp up in difficulty; elementary school word, middle school word, high school word, SAT, etc. Here‚Äôs another example: CASTLE ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Player 1: C Player 2: A Player 3: S Player 1: T Player 2: L Player 3: E ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Host: Can you use it in a sentence? ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Player 1: A Player 2: Castle Player 3: Is Player 1: Where Player 2: The Player 3: Prince Player 1: Lives ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Play at the top of your intelligence, the fun of this game is genuine and honest mistakes rather than contrived and forced mistakes Do your best with keeping up the speed of the game. Don‚Äôt worry too much about being accurate, messing up is fun! Also, try your best to speak in complete sentences.

games.name: Slo-Mo Olympics

setup.description: Olympic event of mundane/non-sport activity. Get suggestion.

rules: Athletes warm up at regular speed while being introduced
Starting pistol fires (or commentators start match)
Athletes switch to slow motion
Commentators describe as high-stakes sporting event
Game ends when athlete crosses finish line or vanquishes opponent

tips: Start strong - welcome audience, introduce yourself, event, then athletes
React to what athletes are pantomiming
Play with athletes - instant replays, zoom in
Lead athletes to actions
Don't talk over fellow commentator
Maintain excitement, avoid dead air
Before match, hint at character - good guy (face) or bad guy (heel)
Play with props related to competition
Go slow when match starts, match competitor's speed
Make pantomiming distinct, especially hands
React big with movements and facial expressions
Earnestly do activity first, then sabotage opponent
Use things related to activity when sabotaging
Do 4-5 fighting beats during slo-mo
Generally bad guy should lose

notes: This can be played with an audience member as an athlete. As the fellow athlete, take care of the audience member and let them win.

games.name: Story

setup.description: Performers tell third-person story, can only speak when host points at them. Get story title.

rules: Performers can only speak when host points at them
When host pulls hand away, performer must stop
Next person picks up EXACTLY where previous left off (mid-sentence/word)
Elimination game - mess ups result in leaving stage
New chapters announced after eliminations
tips: Actions more important than dialogue/description
Avoid delay tactics like "decided to"
Use action words to keep plot going
LISTEN - don't think of your own story
Keep to 3-4 characters
Keep story simple, follow first idea and heighten
Don't solve problems, keep struggle going
Don't worry about messing up - designed to make you fail
Fall on grenade if no one has failed in a while
New chapters = skip ahead in story

setup.description: Fast-paced game where 2 people are on stage as a guest and host of a late night talk show, while the rest of the cast is on the back wall. A suggestion is given and they do a quick riff before the switch is called. The Host (stage left person) leaves, the guest moves over and becomes the Host, and a new guest arrives. A new suggestion is given and this continues like this until time is called. Always jump in the middle of the interview. This game benefits from speed and energy, you want to hit the ground running as soon as you get your suggestion. This is a big moment on this talk show that will be on all of the news stations the next day. Think Tom Cruise jumping on the sofa. Commit to it strongly because the scene will last no more than 10 seconds. It might be called on a really good initiation line Try to incorporate an action into the segment, it can help justify the suggestion rather than just talking about it. Remember the roles of Host & Guest; stick to the format of a talk show but you have freedom to be creative. So if the segment starts with the guest steering the ship to a boat; the Host might respond: "Ladies & Gentlemen, we are about to experience a pillage by none other than Black Beard himself and might I say what a full & black beard it is!" This game benefits from variety, change it up!

A title is received from the audience, and two groups of performers are onstage. One group tells the story, and one person from the other group acts it out (no dialogue or sound effects). The narrative group forms a line and the first person in line starts the story (3rd person perspective). That person keeps telling the story until the person behind them taps them on the back and continues EXACTLY where they left off. The Actor acts out EVERYTHING (characters, objects, concepts, etc.). When the Host shouts "SWITCH", the groups switch roles. The person who is narrating becomes the actor (the other two stand off to the side), and the previous Actor immediately starts narrating (the two who were off to the side form a line behind that new narrator) Narrative Group: Always look straight ahead, do not look at the actors. If you look at them, then your story becomes less progressive because you‚Äôre letting them decide your story. Tap outs start out every 5-10 seconds but as the game progresses, they should be literally every 2-3 seconds. Build the game up to controlled chaos! Stories involve action, description, and dialogue. For most of the story, use action! It's easier for the actor to convey. Avoid the phrase "decided to..." it's a delay tactic and doesn't actually progress the story. Actors: Do not talk, only mime the story. The audience‚Äôs eyes are on you, but their ears are on the storytellers. Big actions and justification! BE EVERYTHING!

4 Performers Needed. Performer A is the main anchor who receives no character endowment. Performer B is the co-anchor, who receives an endowment. We also have Performer C & D who are Sports & Weather; they also receive an endowment. These are weird endowments not from the audience but from the host. The segment begins with some News Intro Music, and both the Anchor and Co-Anchor are onstage. The Main Anchor introduces the show and themselves (usually a weird name (like Giuseppe Supwitdat) or a play on words or a real thing (like Chuck Stake), or even like a prank call name (like Hugh Jazz). The Main Anchor also names the other 3 characters when it comes time for them. This is a good breakdown of timing (It's not definitive, it's just a way to think about it). Music intro (5-10 seconds) Anchor and Co-Anchor onstage doing silent activity (shuffle report documents, checking teeth in mirror, combing hair, something random) Anchor Introduction and Intro to the Story (10-20 seconds) Anchor Introduces Co-Anchor and they Interact (20-30 seconds) Anchor Introduces Sports who then reports (20-30 seconds); ends with something like "Back to You" Anchor and Co-Anchor interact again (10-20 seconds) Anchor Introduces Weather who then reports (20-30 seconds); ends with "Back to You" Anchor closes out segment ("Join us at 10pm to find out how many licks does it take get to the center of a tootsie roll pop"); Last interaction between Anchor and Co-Anchor (10-20 seconds) Music outro (5-10 seconds) Silent activity between anchors to close out segment; last chance for Co-Anchor to close out their character-now silently. Keep it short and sweet. Don't drone on and lose sight of the fact that this is short form. Short form works well with the mentality that you should leave them wanting more. Follow the above time breakdown. You will receive weird and specific quirks. Maybe quirks that make you go "WTF?!" Your job is once the game begins, you need to commit to that quirk as though it's a part of your character portfolio. Don't judge your presentation, don't worry about if you're doing it right, and don't bail on your idea. If you start strong, then judge yourself, and back off your character, you're too in your head. Go full- on! This game will be over before you know it, so have fun playing this character probably for the first and last time ever! Show the fun discovery that you're having. There's a lot of give in this game. "And with me tonight, my co-anchor, Mickey Louse" "And now let's go to Sports reporter Nancy Reginald for predictions for the big game!" "And let's find out what the precipitation is like this weekend with Weather's Rudolph Bignose." "That's sports/weather, back to you!" Be ready to GIVE focus to performers when it's time, BUT also be ready to take focus too. If you feel like it's right to move onto the next part of the game, then take focus and redirect it there. This usually falls onto the Main Anchor. They are the glue that holds the game together since they are playing more straight-laced (no quirk attached). So, whoever the Main Anchor is, keep the game in control, since performers may have big characters that could cause them to lose track of time. This game is weird and absurd, but to you and your newscasters, this is the norm. Don't treat the game as weird. The Main Anchor can show emotion and reactions to the absurdity but treat it more as you have been with these 3 people for years, don't treat it like "This is my first day, and this is WEIRD, right?!?!"
Pun-telling game with specific format. Get noun/category suggestion.

tips: Command that stage - tell joke like it's funniest thing ever
Add physicality to sell joke
Backline supports with laughs, groans, side comments

Face the audience, kill someone with the suggestion, and give a cheesy action hero line. This is all about being really over-the-top and punny. If you have a sucky joke, GREAT! It will work even better if you commit hard to a clich√© action hero (think Arnold and Sylvester). Got nothing? Take a bullet! A good way to do that is to go out and do a really elaborate killing of the person using the object directly. What would killing a person with a slinky look like? That might end of being the joke or it will buy you some time to think of something to say. Remember, your "joke" doesn't suck unless you show the audience it sucks.

games.name: Let Me Tell You Something, Brother

setup.description: Another pun-telling game, but this time you are embodying an 80‚Äôs/90‚Äôs WWF wrestler! You can play with the setup here, but here are the two common ones. If the suggestion was cow: ‚ÄúLet Me Tell You Something, Brother‚Ä¶ They call me the cow (suggestion) because I will UDDERLY destroy you! Or they go straight into it: ‚ÄúLet Me Tell You Something, Brother‚Ä¶ you and me, we got BEEF Rather than show you MUT examples, here is a list of WWF/WWE wrestlers and their famous promos if you ever want to emulate one of them:

Objects are collected from the audience while the players have their back to the audience. The host will put an object on a stool, and the players must use the object in a way that it is not normally used. If it was an umbrella, you can use it as anything except an umbrella. This game is essentially the game of Props, as seen on Whose Line Is It Anyway?, except you'll receive actual objects that audience members would have in their pockets, purses, bags, etc. Just like with Last Action Joke or World's Worst, you need to COMMIT! Use the object and deliver a "punchline" or a line of dialogue to complement what you are doing. It also helps to bring someone out with you to assist. I've included a video to a Props game below. Notice how they successfully use the second person to just help further paint the picture. If the object was an umbrella, you can do a Pinocchio bit by making the umbrella your nose and have it grow when you lie. To paint the picture more clearly, have someone come out with you and be Gepetto. Adding the second person helps make it a mini scene, even if all they do is react. Feel free to also manipulate the object. If it's an umbrella, you can extend it, or open it up. If it's a box of Tic Tacs, you can open it up and use the Tic Tacs themselves to create a scene. Commit!
